loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue investing in baking ingredients and also complimentary goods he sells

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue investing in merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue investing in her restaurant and clothing store

loans.name: I Ketut Sudika

texts.id:
I Ketut Sudika lives in Manistutu village, in addition to his routine job as a farmer, I Ketut Sudika also sells fertilizer. A wide range of fertilizer is available for sale at his house. He entered to this business as he sees that most of his neighbors are farmers, so they will need fertilizer. The farmers in the neighborhood prefer to buy fertilizer from I Ketut Sudika as Ketut provides delivery service and credit facility where his customers can pay for the fertilizer after the harvest. That's why I Ketut Sudika needs additional capital to improve his business. In addition the price of fertilizer has gone up lately. With additional capital from Dinari, I Ketut Sadika can serve more farmers. His family's welfare will also improving and his children can pursue a higher level of education.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

I Ketut Sudika tinggal di desa Manistutu, dalam kesehariannya selain sebagai petani I Ketut Sudika juga menekuni usaha sebagai penjual pupuk. Berbagai macam pupuk tersedia dirumahnya. Usaha ini ditekuni melihat masyarakat disekitar tempat tinggalnya sebagian besar berprofesi sebagai petani ,yang pasti membutuhkan pupuk untuk pertumbuhan padinya. Para petani cenderung membeli pupuk pada I Ketut Sudika karena keistimewaan pelayanan yang diberikan yaitu layanan antar dan juga membayar setelah panen. Oleh sebab itu I Ketut Sudika memerlukan tambahan modal untuk usahanya ini,juga mengingat harga pupuk akhir-akhir ini meningkat drastis. Dengan adanya tambahan modal dari Dinari ,maka I Ketut Sudika dapat tetap menjalankan usahanya dan melayani petani lebih banyak lagi. Sehingga perekonomian keluarganya dapat terbantu dan anak-anaknya dapat melanjutkan sekolah ke jenjang yang lebih tinggi. Ia sangat berterimakasih kepada Dinari atas pinjaman yang telah diberikan.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer (Membeli pupuk)

loans.name: I Ketut Surja

texts.id:
Manistutu village is a village with a fertile land, the Subak organization (Subak is a traditional way where a group of farmer get together to organize irrigation for their land) is running well. In this village I Ketut Surja lives with his wife and children. Ketut Surja is a farmer, planting paddy seed. The land that he works on is quite large so he needs additional workers to work on his land. However so far the product of his land is not so good. This is because the limitation from capital point of view where Ketut cannot afford to buy high quality paddy seeds, good fertilizer and good pesticide. At the moment Ketut is only using local paddy seeds and adds fertilizer and pesticide once and a while as they are quite expensive. With the loan from Dinari, Ketut Surja is hoping that his harvest will improve as he is using a good quality seeds, fertilizer and also good pesticide. If his harvest successful he will be able to improve his family's welfare.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Desa Manistutu merupakan desa yang subur, pengaturan Subak ( organisasi petani dalam hal pengaturan air ) nya sangat bagus sehingga pengairan disawah menjadi lancar. Didesa inilah I Ketut Surja tinggal bersama istri dan anak-anaknya. Ketut Surja menekuni usaha sebagai petani yang bercocok tanam dengan menanam padi. Lahan yang dikerjakan cukup luas,sehingga ia memerlukan buruh untuk mengerjakan sawahnya ini. Namun hasil padi yang dipanen selama ini tidak bagus. Hal ini disebabkan karena keterbatasan dana yang dimiliki oleh Ketut Surja, sehingga dia tidak bisa membeli bibit dengan kwalitas unggul ,maupun cara pemberian pupuk dan pengobatan yang bagus. Ketut Surja hanya menggandalkan bibit lokal saja ,dan pemupukannya pun hanya sekedar, pemberantasan hama tidak dilakukan secara tuntas mengingat harga obat-obatan meningkat drastis. Tapi sekarang dengan adanya pinjaman dari Dinari Ketut Surja berharap panennya tidak gagal lagi,karena bibit yang digunakan merupakan bibit unggul dan cara pemupukan serta pengobatan padi pun sudah dilakukan dengan baik. Apabila panennya berhasil otomatis ekonomi keluarga pun akan menjadi lebih baik dan sejahtera.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, paddy seeds and pesticide (Membeli pupuk, bibit padi berkwalitas dan obat - obatan anti hama)

loans.name: Ni Ketut Winarti

texts.id:
Every morning, at 9 am, Winarti feeds her 3 pigs. This job has become a routine after finishing other household chores. She owns an iron pen that in her backyard to contain her farmed pigs. This business helps her a lot in fulfilling her family's financial needs. Winarti has a child that she needs to take care of. She is highly motivated in pursuing this business as it helps her husband tremendously. Her husband's rice farming income is quite uncertain. She earns decent income. Each 6 months, she can sell 3 piglets and gain $132 profit. This earnings is used to pay for her child's tuition. Currently, Winarti needs additional funding of $275 to make improve her pig pen to improve her pig's health and quality. The rest of the loan will be used to purchase better quality feed to improve the health of the pigs.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Setiap pukul 09:00 wita, Winarti memberi makan 3 ekor babi peliharaannya. Pekerjaan ini tentunya sudah menjadi rutinitas kesehariaannya setelah selesai memasak didapur. Kandang besi yang dimiliki dibelakang rumah, sebagai tempat untuk menampung babi yang dipelihara. Usaha ini sangat membantu dalam memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Winarti memiliki satu orang anak yang masih menjadi tanggungannya. Semangat untuk menukuni usaha yang dimilikinya, membuat suaminya sangat senang karena sangat meringankan beban sebagai kepala rumah tangga. Karena, penghasilan suami yang tidak menentu sebagai seorang petani . Keuntungan yang sudah dirasakan sangat memuaskan. Dalam 6 bulan, 3 bibit babi ini bisa di jual dan mendapatkan keuntungan Rp.1.200.000,- bersih. Keuntungan ini digunakan untuk biaya sekolah anaknya. Saat ini Winarti membutuhkan tambahan modal untuk usahanya sebesar Rp. 2.500.000.- yang akan dipergunakan untuk membuat kandang babi yang lebih permanen lagi supaya babinya bisa berkembang dengan baik tidak seperti sekarang ini tanpa atap. Sisanya nanti akan dipergunakan untuk membeli pakan ternak yang lebih berkwalitas demi pertumbuhan babinya

loans.use: Improve Pig Pen and Buy Feeds

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Saman

texts.id:
The house where Ni Nyoman Saman lives is very simple and it is shared with other families. While the backyard is not big, Saman uses it to farm pigs as she wants to assist her husband in getting extra money to meet their daily needs. In 6 month, she can get a net proceed of IDR 1 million (approx USD 105). This proceed is used to assist the family needs and also to be saved. At the moment she needs additional capital to expand her pig farming by purchasing more piglets.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Rumah tempat tinggal Ni Nyoman Saman sangat sederhana dan masih berkumpul dengan keluarga yang lain. Walaupun pekarangan tidak begitu luas, Saman tetap bahagia terutama semangat dalam membantu suami mencari nafkah. Terbukti 2 bibit babi yang dipelihara sangat gemuk karena Saman sangat rajin memberi makan dan menjaga kesehatan babinya. Selain memberi makan dedak padi dan dedak gandum, juga diberi makanan tambahan seperi batang pisang dan juga dedaunan. Saman senang bila tiba saatnya pelanggan babi datang untuk membeli babinya. Karena keuntungan yang diterima sangat membantu kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Dalam 6 bulan bisa meraup keuntungan Rp.1.000.000,- bersih. Keuntungan ini akan digunakan untuk membantu suaminya dalam memenuhi kebutuhan hidup setiap hari dan juga ditabung. Saat ini Saman membutuhkan tambahan modal didalam usahanya untuk membeli bibit yang baru yang lebih banyak agar usaha ini bisa maju dan berkembang.

loans.use: To buy piglets (Membeli bibit babi)

loans.name: Ni Ketut Suartini

texts.id:
Ketut Suartini wants to help her husband as her husband is only a simple farmer who cannot get enough money to meet their family daily needs. With the loan, Suartini bought 1 breeding pig and 2 piglets. At the moment the breeding pig is only tied to a tree because she doesn't have a hut. The 2 piglets are farmed inside a small simple bamboo hut. In 6 month, she can get a net proceed of IDR 2 millions (approx. USD 210). This farming business provide significant support for her family. With the future loan, she would like to build a larger permanent pig hut so all of the pigs can be farmed inside the hut.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Walaupun dengan kandang bambu yang sederhana, Ketut Suartini tetap berkeinginan membantu suami dalam memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Karena hasil suami yang didapat dari bertani, tidak mencukupi biaya sehari hari. Dengan modal pinjaman yang ada, Suartini membeli 1 induk babi dan 2 ekor bibit babi penggemukan. Setiap hari Suartini memberi makan babi peliharaannya sebanyak 3 kali. Tak lupa juga kandang disiram agar bersih dan segar, sehingga babi peliharaannya bisa sehat dan gemuk. Makanan yang diberikan berupa pakan dedak gandum yang dibeli di toko, kadang juga dedaunan untuk makanan tambahan. Induk babi hanya diikat dipohon karena belum memiliki modal untuk membuat kandang. 2 ekor bibit babi dikurung dikandang bambu. Dalam enam bulan Suartini bisa maraup keuntungan Rp.2.000.000,- bersih dari hasil induk dan bibit babi. Usaha ini sangat menunjang biaya hidup Surtini, bahkan untuk kedepannya Suartini ingin membeli bibit lebih dari 2 ekor. Agar usahanya bisa maju dan berkembang. Dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya nanti, Suartini juga berencana untuk membuat kandang yang permanen dan lebih besar lagi sehingga semua babinya tinggal didalam kandang dan bisa berkembang biak dengan baik.

loans.use: To build a larger pig hut (Membuat kandang permanen yang lebish besar sehingga semua babi tertampung didalamnya)

loans.name: Ni Luh Sutini

texts.id:
Apart from her regular job as a worker in local village administrative office, Sutini and her husband also have a pig farming business. At the moment she has 2 breeding pigs. A good team work with her husband makes this pig farming business successful and they can meet their household daily needs. They both live in a simple house with a 5 year old daughter. The proceed that they can get from the selling of piglets produced by these 2 breeding pigs in one year is IDR 4 million (approx. USD 420). This proceed is used to buy pig feed and to improve the pig hut. The future loan will be used to buy another breeding pig so they can improve the revenue that they get from the farming business.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Selain bekerja sebagai karyawati di Kantor Desa didesanya, Sutini dan suaminya memiliki usaha memelihara babi. Saat ini Sutini memelihara 2 ekor induk babi. Kekompakan dalam berusaha bersama suami membuat usaha ini berhasil dan bisa memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Mereka tinggal dirumah yang sangat sederhana, dengan 1 orang anak perempuan yang masih berumur 5 tahun. Keuntungan yang didapat dari 2 induk babinya dalam 1 tahun, sebesar Rp.4.000.000,- dari penjualan anak – anaknya. Keuntungan ini digunakan untuk membeli pakan ternak dan memperbaiki kandang. Pinjaman kedepan akan digunakan untuk membeli 1 ekor induk babi lagi, agar keuntungan yang diterima lebih banyak dan bisa menopang kebutuhan keluarganya.

loans.use: To buy a breeding pig (Membeli induk babi)

loans.name: Chhouk

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhouk and her family live in Koh Dach Island on the Mekong River. She married in 1973 and has six children: three sons and three daughters. Three of the children live in separate houses; the others live with her. She and her husband, Man, are farmers. They grow fruits and vegetables, such as tomatoes and papaya, and make jam, and sell them at the market in Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Chhouk is requesting her seventh loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $400 to buy more silk products for her daughter to sell.

loans.use: To purchase silk products to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Thoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Thoeurn lives along National Road Number 05 on the way to Battambong Province. She married in 2002 and has a son and a daughter. She has finished grade seven in a secondary school, but her husband, Vuthy, has finished a university degree and her son is studying in a kindergarten school. She learned to sew from a neighbor and started her own business in 2001. Meanwhile, her husband teaches English at home. He has taught for over seven years.

Mrs. Thoeurn is requesting her first loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $700 to buy clothes and fix the house where she lives.

loans.use: To buy clothes and fix her house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Siang

texts.id:
Ni Nyoman Siang and her husband live by themselves. Their children are all grown up and already married and live by themselves. Even though they no longer have someone to support but they can only live with minimum standard. Both of them work together to support their life. They choose to farm piglets. They farm 1 breeding pig and 1 piglets in traditional ways by attaching them in a tree because they don't have money to build a hut. In 6 month they can get a proceed of IDR 1.5 million (approx. USD 157). At the moment she needs additional capital to build a permanent hut.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Diusia yang sudah setengah baya, Ni Nyoman Siang dan suami hanya tinggal berdua. Anak-anak mereka sudah menikah dan sudah mandiri. Walaupun mereka sudah tidak punya tanggungan, tetapi tetap saja hidup mereka pas-pasan. Mereka berdua bekerjasama untuk berusaha lain. Hanya memelihara babi usaha yang tepat untuk mereka jalani. Dengan memelihara 1 induk dan 1 penggemukan,Siang sangat menikmati kesibukan yang dilakukan setiap hari.3 kali dalam 1 hari babi peliharaannya diberi makan. Babi peliharaannya dipelihara secara tradisional diikat dipohon karena Ni Nyoman Siang belum memiliki modal untuk membuat kandang. Dalam 6 bulan mendapat keuntungan Rp.1.500.000,- Biasanya anak-anak babinya dibeli oleh warga setempat. Sehingga bila induk babinya beranak, Ni Nyoman Siang mendapat uang dan keuntungan. Ni Nyoman Siang sangat senang menjalani usaha ini. Saat ini Ni Nyoman Siang membutuhkan tambahan modal usaha yang nantinya akan dipergunakan untuk membuat kandang yang lebih layak dari sekarang supaya babi yang dipeliharanya tidak lagi diikat dibawah pohon.

loans.use: To build a permanent hut (Membuat kandang yang permanen)

loans.name: Sophorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophorn was married in 1968, but she is now a widow with seven children: three boys and four girls. One of the children has married and the others are single. This family lives along National Road Number 05 on the way to Battambong Province. They are all very kind and friendly.

Mrs. Sophorn has been selling groceries in the village since 2000. She buys most of grocery items from a market in Phnom Penh. She is requesting her fourth loan from MAXIMA in the amount of $1000 to purchase more grocery items, such as candy, oranges, bananas, and cake, to sell in her neighborhood.

loans.use: To buy more grocery items

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for MAXIMA Mikroheranhvatho Co., Ltd. - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en: Rustam J. was born in 1954 in Asht, Tajikistan. He is married and has 5 children. Mr J. is an active client of  MicroInvest who has recommended himself as a reliable  borrower. He has a home business in  livestock raising and  milk production. Mr J. is a foreman in his profession. The main business he is engaged in is livestock. He has a large flock. Now Mr J. requests a loan of $725 for a mixed fodder purchase.

loans.use: for a mixed fodder purchase

loans.name: Ni Nyoman Madri

texts.id:
Ni Nyoman Madri, 64 year old, is a single woman, living without a husband. Ni Nyoman Madri enjoys her living alone and even she still has enthusiasms to enjoy her live. With the loan given, she lives her daily life with farming 2 piglets. This is the only activity and the only source of income for her. Ni Nyoman Madri only finished her primary school and up to now she's still living with her family as she's not married. These piglets will be sold in 5 months and she can get a net proceed of IDR 600 thousand (approx of USD 63). She already has the buyer who will buy her piglets. With the future loan, she wants to purchase another 2 piglets and to build a bamboo hut for her piglets.

Translated from Indonesian by Antonius Gunadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Ni Nyoman Madri adalah seorang wanita yang hidup tanpa suami, hanya seorang diri sampai usianya yang sekarang ini, 64 tahun. Ni Nyoman Madri sangat menikmati kesendiriannya. Bahkan semangat dalam dirinya untuk berusaha tetap berkobar. Dengan pinjaman yang diberikan, Ni Nyoman Madri mengisi keseharian dengan memelihara 2 bibit babi penggemukan. Hanya usaha inilah yang bisa ditekuninya, karena Ni Nyoman Madri hanya tamat SD. Ni Nyoman Madri masih tinggal dengan keluarganya karena Ni Nyoman Madri belum menikah. Babi yang dipeliharanya ini dipanen dalam 5 bulan dan mendapat keuntungan Rp.600.000,- bersih. Ni Nyoman Mandri sudah mempunyai pelanggan yang datang untuk membeli babinya. Keuntungan ini sangat menunjang dan membantu keluarga yang sekarang bersamanya. Kedepannya, dengan pinjaman yang didapatnya Ni Nyoman Madri ingin menambah bibit babi lagi 2 ekor dan memperbaiki kandang bambunya.

loans.use: To buy piglets and to build pig hut (Membeli bibit babi dan membuat kandang)

loans.name: Mukaram

texts.en: Mukaram K. was born in 1961 in Asht, Tajikistan. She is divorced and has 4 children. Mrs Mukaram K.  has her own business in  livestock raising and selling and milk products making. It is the family business. She has the appropriate skills in livestock (she is experienced in the business for 10 years) which is why she has a large flock. In spite the fact that it is a very hard business she manages the livestock successfully. Now Mrs K.  requests the loan of $1200 to complete the building of a barn for her cows and bulls.

loans.use: To complete the construction of a barn for her cows and bulls.

loans.name: Gairatjon

texts.en: Gairatjon K.  is 22 years old and he lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. Mr.K. is engaged in the family business of  livestock raising and selling. It is the general business income that he has. He has a large flock of pedigree bulls. Now Mr K. requests a loan of $650 f to be repaid in 8 months for a mixed fodder purchase.

loans.use: a  mixed fodder purchase

loans.name: Alisher

texts.en: Alisher M.  lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. In spite the fact that he is a young man (he is 22 years old) he is rather experienced in business. Mr.M. has recommended himself as a serious and reliable client. He is engaged in  livestock raising and selling. He has a large flock and the large barn. Now Mr.M. requests a loan of $650 to be repaid in  8 months for the barn completion. It  will permit  him to increase the size of his flock number.

loans.use: for a barn completion

loans.name: Marach B(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Esther N.. She is currently in the business of charcoal selling and is requesting a loan to expand her charcoal business. Esther is 48 years old and is married with a husband who is a businessman. She has 5 children ranging in age from 5 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Esther makes approximately UGX 50000 (US$29.00) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay rent for the charcoal store and school fees for the children. Esther took a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 (US$291.00) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Esther is joined in her small group by Christine S., Margret N. and Betty A.. Christine S. owns a small hotel and wants to buy more furniture and hotel equipment. Margret N. currently sells matooke (plantain) and wants a loan to increase her stock. Betty A. sells charcoal and wants to expand her business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business

loans.name: Marach B(V) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Saida S.. She currently sells new clothes and is requesting a loan to invest in her business. Saida is 23 years old and is married; her husband works in an immigration office. She has 1 son. Each week, Saida makes approximately UGS 30000 (US$18.00) in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to complete her house, which is under construction. Saida has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGS 500000 (US$291.00) in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Saida is joined in her small group by Sauda K., Mary O. and Mariam T.. Sauda K. sells new clothes and wants to start a shoe business with the loan. Mary O. is currently operating a business in dry foods and wants a loan to expand. Mariam T. operates sells new clothes and wants to increase her stock for sale.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale

loans.name: Rano

texts.en:
Rano C. is 40 years old. She is married with three children of school age.

Five years ago Rano decided to start her own business for the purpose of  improving the economic position of the family. Rano is selling shoes for kids in the local market. The husband of Rano was unemployed for a long time and not so recently he left for Russia to earn some money. Because of that, Rano’s business currently is the main source of income for supporting  her family. 

The spring is coming soon, and Rano will have to purchase  shoes for kids for the spring season. With this purpose she requests a loan of $600.00 US Dollars for the term of 10 months. Rano thanks all for their support and promises to pay the loan on time.

loans.use: Purchasing of  shoes for kids for the spring season for selling.

loans.name: Muborak

texts.en:
A. Muborak is 54 years old. She and her husband have raised three children, the elder is already married. 

For 11 years Muborak has been running her own business. She is selling  socks in the central local market. As a rule she receives the goods from the  neighboring city of Istaravshan. Considering that the husband of Muborak is currently unemployed, her business is the main source of income for the family. Muborak is working hard and hoping to educate her younger children and to improve the living conditions of the family.

Today Muborak requests 200.00 US Dollars for the term of 3 months. She is planning to enlarge the range of goods for selling. Muborak promises to pay the loan in time.

loans.use: Purchasing of goods like socks for men and women in order to enlarge the range of goods

loans.name: Mawero East A(I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Sadi R.. She currently sells charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Sadi is 40 years old and is married; her husband sells matooke (plantain). She has 3 children ranging in age from 18 to 22. Each week, Sadi makes approximately UGS 40000 (US$24.00) in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to complete her house, which is under construction. Sadi has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGS 300000 (US$175) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Sadi is joined in her small group by Kadija K., Annet S. and Zaituni N.. Kadija K. sells charcoal sales and wants to increase her stock. Annet S., who also sells charcoal, wants a loan to expand and become a wholesaler. Zaituni N. operates a retail shop and wants to use the loan to increase stock in the shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand a charcoal business

loans.name: Mawero East A (Ii) Group

texts.en:
Joan N., the leader of this small group, sells used clothes and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Joan is 26 years old and is married; her husband is a market vendor . Her 3 children, ranging in age from 3 to 7 years, go to school. Each week, Joan makes approximately UGS 70000 (US$40) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to pay school fees for the children. Joan has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGS 300000 (USD$175) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Joan is joined in her small group by Agatha T. and Oliver N.. Both Agatha T. and Oliver N. sell used clothes and want a loan to expand their businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand a clothing business

loans.name: Ibroim

texts.en: Ibroim M. lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. He is married and has 5 children. Mr. M.  has recommended himself as a serious client who trusts the MicroInvest loan procedure. He is a collective farmer but he is engaged in the home business of the livestock raising and selling. He dreams of having the large flock and that is why Mr.M. requests the loan of $650 for 8 months to purchase a pedigree bull  This will permit him to increase his flock number significantly.

loans.use: for  pedigree bull purchasing

loans.name: Solo Fb Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Jane N.. She sells used clothes and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Jane is 33 years old and is married. Her husband is a mechanic. She has 4 children ranging in age from 2 months to 13 years. Three of the children go to school. Each week, Jane makes approximately UGS 40000 (US$24.00) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to pay school fees for the children Jane has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGS 150000 (US$88.00) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Jane is joined in her small group by Christine K. and Zam M.. Christine K. sells dry fish and wants to expand her business. Zam M. is currently operating a business in tailoring and selling clothes and wants a loan to buy another sewing machine and more cloth.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes for sale

loans.name: Mawero East A (Iii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Beatrice T.. She currently sells both new and used clothes and is requesting a loan to invest in her business. Beatrice is 42 years old and is married; her husband is a businessman. She has 7 children ranging in age from 9 to 20 years and her children go to school. Each week, Beatrice makes approximately UGX 150000 (US$88.00) in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Beatrice has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 (US$350.00) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Beatice is joined in her small group by Robina N. and Sarah B.. Robina N. sells charcoal and wants to purchase more charcoal for sale. Sarah B. sells used clothes and wants a loan to expand her business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Bahromjon

texts.en: Bahromjon D. is 21 years old and he lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. Mr D. is a very serious and single-minded young man who is full of enthusiasm and readiness to work. He is an orphan but it does not influence his desire to have a good  family. Mr.D. is ready to work hard to earn money for a future marriage . He is a collective farmer and besides he trades in raw yarn and the warm socks in the bazaar. He works with a direct supplier that is why he trades in prices that are lower than the bazaar prices. He has direct suppliers from the China. Now Mr D. requests a loan of $650 to purchase a lot of new warm socks.

loans.use: the new warm socks lot purchasing

loans.name: Khojalbuvy

texts.en: Khojalbuvy M. lives in the Asht region of Tajikistan. She is married and has 5 children.  Mrs. M. applied to the MicroInvest because she heard many successful business stories. She is engaged in the family business of  socks yam and selling. It is the business where her daughter and daughter-in-law help her. Mrs M. has serious problems with her health.  She has been engaged in this work  all her life so she is very experienced and ready to share her experience. Now Mrs. M. requests a loan of $650 for 8 months for a new kind of raw yarn purchasing.

loans.use: a new kind of raw yarn purchasing

loans.name: Murodjon

texts.en:
Muridjon N. is 32 years old. He is married with two children of school age.

Murodjon is a cattleman. He purchases the cattle in the local market, raises it and then sells it.  Currently he has  one cow and one calf in his household. Murodjon is not so experienced as he has only been in this business  for 2 years. However, already now the business brings the main significant income to the family allowing him to support the family.

Murodjon managed to make certain savings and he needs additional funds to purchase another 2 cows for  breeding. For this purpose he requests 300.00 US Dollars for the term of 10 months. This is the first loan of Murodjon, however, he is sure he shall be able to pay it in time and thanks all for their trust in him

loans.use: Purchasing of 2 more cows for breeding

loans.name: Muborack

texts.en: Muborack O. lives in Asht, Tajikistan.  She is married and has 4 children. Mrs.O. is a new client of  MicroInvest but she is experienced in business (about 8 years). She has a trade outlet in the bazaar where she trades in material and self-sewed national dresses. She is a skilled dressmaker. Mrs.O. has a wide assortment with different colored material  and a variety of national dresses. Now Mrs.O. requests the loan of $650 for a new material lot purchase.

loans.use: a new material lot purchase

loans.name: Mugunza A(I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Shamim N.. She currently sells used clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes for sale. Shamim is 30 years old and is married. She has 3 children ranging from age 5 to 14 and her children go to school. Each week, Shamim makes approximately UGX 150000 (US$88.00) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to complete the roofing of her new house. Shamim has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 (US$290.00) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Shamim is joined in her small group by Ruth A. and Juliet N.. Ruth A. sells textbooks and stationary and wants to expand her business. Juliet N. currently sells dried fish and wants a loan to expand the business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand used clothing business

loans.name: Mugunza A(V) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Teopista Akwase. She currently sells used clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes for sale. Teopista is 33 years old and is married; her husband is a conductor . She has 6 children ranging in age from 1 to 20 years and five of them go to school. Each week, Teopista makes approximately UGX 50000 (US$30.00) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to pay school fees for the children. Teopista has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 (US$118.00) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Teopista is joined in her small group by Jane A., Jane A. and Lilian T.. Jane A. sells milk and wants to buy more milk cans. Jane A. sells dry foods and wants a loan to increase her stock. Lilian T. sells maize flour and wants to expand her business with the loan.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Tiira Road F Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Edith N.. She currently sells matooke (plantain) and is requesting a loan to purchase more matooke for sale. Edith is 28 years old and is married. She has 6 children ranging in age from 1.5 to 10 years and five of them go to school. Each week, Edith makes approximately UGX 35000 (US$20.00) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to pay school fees for the children. Edith has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 (US$118.00) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Edith is joined in her small group by Sarah N. and Hadija N.. Both Sarah N. and Hadija N. sell used clothes and they wants a loan to increase their businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To purchase mroe matooke for sale and make more profits

loans.name: Mugunza A(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Musa Namugosa. She currently sells dry foods and is requesting a loan to increase her stock. Musa is 30 years old and is married; her husband is a businessman. She has 3 children ranging in age from 3.5 to 11years and her children go to school. Each week, Musa makes approximately UGX 30000 (US$18.00) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to pay school fees for her late sisters' children. Musa has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 (US$290) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Musa is joined in her small group by Betty T., Annet N. and Annet A.. Betty T. sells maize flour and wants to expand her business. Annet N. currently sells charcoal and wants a loan to expand her business. Annet A. sells dried fish and wants to expand her business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Mugunza A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Hamida H.. She operates a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase her stock. Hamida is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a businessman. She has 3 children ranging in age from 6 to 12 years and her children go to school. Each week, Hamida makes approximately UGX 70000 (US$41.00) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a new refrigerator for her shop. Hamida has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000(US$175.00) to add more stock in the shop and the loan was paid back on time.

Hamida is joined in her small group by Zubeda D. and Aisha N.. Zubeda D. sells used clothes and wants to expand the business. Aisha N. currently operates a retail shop and wants a loan to add stock in the shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Mugunza A(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Hamida H.. She is currently in the business of retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase stock in shop. Hamida is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 3 children ranging from age 6 to 12 and her children go to school. Each week, Hamida makes approximately UGX 70000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a new fridge for her shop. Hamida has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her busienss by add in more stock in the shop and the loan was paid back on time.

Hamida is joined in her small group by Zubeda D. and Aisha N.. Zubeda D. has a business in selling used clothes and wants to add in clothe business. Aisha N. is currently operating a business in retail shop and wants a loan to add stock in the shop.

loans.use: To add in retail shop and increase stock

loans.name: Nangwe Madibira (I) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Sarah Acheno. She currently sells dry foods and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Sarah is 35 years old and is married. She has seven children, ranging in age from 8 to 18, who attend school. Each week, Sarah makes approximately UGX 70000 (US$40.00) in profit. With the extra profit she will make with the help of a loan, she hopes to pay the school fees for her children. Sarah has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before, to the amount of UGX 600000 (US$353.00), to invest in her business by increasing the stock in the shop. The loan was paid back on time.

Sarah is joined in her small group by Prisca W., Mariam M., Anda A. and Tausi G.. Prisca W. sells millet flour. Mariam M. has a cosmetics shop. Anda A. operates a hardware shop and Tausi G. sells maize flour. All four women request the loan to expand their businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Mugunza A(Vi) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Winnie L.. She currently owns a hotel and is requesting a loan to expand her hotel business. Winnie is 30 years old and is married. She has 4 children ranging in age from 3 to 10 years and her children go to school. Each week, Winnie makes approximately UGX 70000 (US$41.00) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to buy more furniture for the hotel. Winnie has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 100000 (US$59.00) to invest in her business by adding more stock in the shop and the loan was paid back on time.

Winnie is joined in her small group by Esname A. and Madina N.. Esname A. sells maize flour and Madina N. operates a business hotel. Both women want a loan to expand their businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Cheri Mai

texts.en:
Cheri Mai M. is a shopkeeper in Thecho, Village. Thecho is located in Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this area are engaged in farming. Mrs. M. lives in a joint family home with her father-in-law, mother-in-law, her husband and her four children. Her husband Mr. Tulshi M. works in a private office. Her older son is a teacher and her younger son is in grade 7. Her two daughters are studying in grades 11 and 8 respectively.
Mrs. M. opened her grocery shop 4 years ago. She sells different types of grocery items such as rice, maize, pulse, biscuits, and noodles in her shop. Her children also help her in her work. The demand for grocery goods is increasing in that area so she is requesting her second loan of Rs 15000 to buy grocery items to meet the demand. She is very grateful for your support. 
She spends the major part of her income to give a better education for her children.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Tiira Road A Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Agnes A.. She sells dried fish and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Agnes is 26 years old and is married. Each week, Agnes makes approximately UGX 50000 (US$30) in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to complete her house, which is under construction. Agnes has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 (US$290.00) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Agnes is joined in her small group by Christine A., Jane A., Gertrude R., and Annet A.. Christine A. sells ripe bananas and wants to expand her business. Jane A. and Gertrude R. each sell charcoal and want a loan to increase their stock. Annet A. also sells charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal from the villages.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To add in fish business

loans.name: Jagatha Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Jagatha Maiya M. lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family home with her husband Mr. Mahendra M., a son and two daughters. Her older daughters are studying in grade 11 and 8 respectively. Her son is in primary school.

Mrs. M. opened a grocery shop two years ago to uplift the living standard of her family. Their condition is not good so they can't provide a better education for their children because in Nepal the cost of education is very high comparative to the income. To overcome this problem she opened a grocery shop.

Due to a lack of funds she can’t buy goods in her shop. So she is asking for her second loan of Rs 15000 to buy goods like rice, dal, noodles, and other items.

She needs to provide a better education for her children and wishes to help her husband upgrade the quality of life for her family.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Nangwe Madibira (Ii) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Angella A.. She operates a hardware shop and is requesting a loan to increase her stock. Angella is 41 years old and is married. Her husband is a farmer. She has 3 children ranging in age from 7 to 10 years and they all go to school.Each week, Angella makes approximately UGX 100000(US$59.00) in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. Angella has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 (US$290.00) to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Angella is joined in her small group by Rashid M., Elizabeth N. and Florence M.. Rashid M. sells millet flour, while Elizabeth N. and Florence M. each sell hardware. All three women plan to use the loan to expand their businesses.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand hardware business by increasing stock

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad is a 24 year old young man. Ahmad is single and lives with his family in Tyre, in south Lebanon.
Ahmad sells car tyres and needs a loan to buy new merchandise. Ahmad is a micro entrepreneur who is determined to do the best he can to sustain and develop his business.

loans.use: To buy new merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Prem Kumari

texts.en:
Mrs. Prem Kumari M. is a 38 year old woman who lives in Thecho, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family home with her husband, a son and a daughter. Her daughter is studying in grade 6 and her son is in grade 2. Her husband, Rabindra M. and herself make traditional idols. In Nepal, idol making work is very famous and the demand for idols is increasing. So they need money to buy raw materials to make traditional idols to meet the demand of idols.

So she seeks a Rs 15000 loan to buy raw materials for making traditional idols like gold, wax, silver, etc. for her work.

She wants to invest and spend her money to ensure a better education for her children and uplift the standard of living in her family.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 22 year old man who lives with his family in south Lebanon, in Tyre. Ali works to provide for himself and his wife. He owns a bakery and wants to develop his business so as to be able to continue building his house. Ali needs a loan to buy provisions to increase his productivity.

loans.use: To buy provisions

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

She has 5 children ranging from 4 to 22 years of age and only two boys go to school. Each week, Lukya makes approximately UGX 20000 in profits and, with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to pay school fees for her two sons Lukya has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 1000000 to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Lukya is joined in her small group by Annet M., Adya K. and Immaculate A.. Annet M. has a retail shop and wants to purchase more shop items. Adya K. is currently sells hardwareand wants a loan to expand her business. Immaculate A. also sells hardware sales and wants to add stock to her hardware shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.name: Ram Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Ram Maiya K. is a resident of Thecho who lives in a joint family home with her mother-in-law, husband and three daughters. Thecho village is one of the developing villages of Lalitpur district. The majority of people in this region are engaged in farming.

Her husband Mr. Sanu Maharjan is in Saudi Arabia. He went there to earn money for his family. Her two older daughters are studying in grades 7 and 6 respectively. Her younger daughter is in primary school.

Mrs. K. is a shopkeeper in Thecho village. She sells different types of grocery items in her shop. Her two older daughters help her in her work.

Now, Mrs. K. is requesting her third loan of Rs 20000 to expand her business and buy grocery items for her shop.

loans.use: To buy grocery goods

loans.name: Hassan

texts.en: Hassan is a 32 year old father of 3. He lives with his family in south Lebanon, in Tyre. Hassan owns a bakery and is doing the best he can with the bakery  to provide for his wife and children. Ali needs a loan to buy new materials to increase his business productivity.

loans.use: To buy new materials for his bakery

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Dev Maiya

texts.en:
Miss Dev Maiya M. is a 50 year old lady who lives in Thecho village. Thecho is one of the underdeveloped villages of Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. She lives with her father, mother and her brother. Ms.Dev Maiya M. and her brother opened their shop 10 years ago. They sell different types of steel goods such as jugs, plates, water carrying pots, etc. from their shop. Income from the shop is the only source of income for their family.

Now Dev Maiya M. is requesting a loan of Rs 15000 to expand their business and buy necessary items for their shop.

loans.use: To buy goods items for her shop

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 49 year old father of 6. He lives with his family in south Lebanon, in Tyre. Ibrahim is in the cattle business and also sells milk and yoghurt. He is doing the best he can to provide for his wife and children. Ibrahim needs a loan to buy livestock to sustain and develop his business.

loans.use: To buy livestock

Her son is studying in grade 5.

Mrs. S. and her husband Mr. Dal Bahadur S. are both engaged in mushroom farming. They sell their product at the local market and supply local shops.

Now Mrs. S. seeks a Rs 10000 loan to buy fertilizer and mushroom seeds for their work.

He is determined to generate enough revenue to buy a car to use for his business transportation work. He is doing the best he can to sustain and develop his business.

loans.name: Sanu Maiya

texts.en:
Mrs. Sanu Maiya S. is a 30 year old lady who lives in Chappagaun, Lalitpur. She lives in a single family home with her husband and two children. Her daughter and son are studying in primary school.

Mrs. S. and her husband Mr. Dil Krishna S. opened their meat shop 4 years ago. They sell chicken and buff meat in their shop. The demand for meat is increasing rapidly in that area. Therefore Mrs. S. is requesting her second term loan of Rs 15000 to buy chicken and buff meat for her shop.

loans.name: Nangwe Madibira (V) Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Hellen B.. She is currently in the business of selling maize flour and is requesting a loan to purchase additional flour for the business. Hellen is 36 years old and married. Her husband is a businessman. She has 5 children ranging in age from 2 to 18, and all go to school. Each week, Hellen makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Hellen previously received a loan from BRAC Uganda in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business, and the loan was paid back on time.

Hellen is joined in her small group by Faima M., Sarah N. and Hindu B. . Faima M. has a business selling new clothes and wants to increase her stock. Sarah N. is currently operating a business in clothing sales and wants a loan to expand the business. Hindu B. sells clothes and wants to purchase more clothes for sale.

loans.use: TO purchase more maize flour for sale

loans.name: Jagatha Maiya

texts.en:
Jagatha Maiya D. lives in Chappagaun village. Chappagaun village is located in Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. D. lives in a single family home with her husband and two sons. Her husband Mr. Narandra D. is a taxi driver and drives his taxi in Kathmandu village. Her older son is in grade 5 and younger son is in pre-primary school.

Mrs. D. undertakes mushroom farming. She took 6 months of training in this work. She sells her product in the local market. People also come to her place and buy mushrooms from her. The demand for mushrooms is increasing in that area so Mrs. D. is requesting her 2nd term loan of Rs15000 to buy fertilizers and mushroom seeds for her work.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and mushrooms for her work

loans.name: Sabur

texts.ru:
Sabur K. has been our successful client since 2004. He is married and has one son. His wife stays at home and helps Sabur's mother with house chores. Sabur has been a businessman for 10 years. Sabur used to sell video cassettes on the streets. Having received his first loan from MicroInvest, he increased the volume of sales and successfully paid back his loan. Next, Sabur saved his money and opened his own store; today he has a wide variety of DVDs and many permanent clients not only among local consumers, but also consumers from outlying regions. Savur came to Kiva in hopes of receiving a new loan for the purchase of an additional DVD player and a quantity of DVDs.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Каримов Сабур является одним из успешных наших клиентов с 2004 года. Он женат и имеет одного сына.Жена домохозайка,помогает его матери по дому. Торговлей он занимается на протяжении 10 лет. Раньше Сабур торговал касетами для аудио аппаратуры на улице. После получения первого займа с Микроинвеста он увеличил объём своей продукции и успешно погасил займ. В дальнейшем он накопил деньги на собственный магазин и сегодня он имеет большой выбор дисков и много постоянных клиентов не только местных потребтителей, но и с отдаленных районов. В Киву он обратился с просьбой на получение займа на покупку дополнительного DVD и закупку новых дисков для записи.

loans.use: Purchase of an additional DVD player and DVDs

loans.name: Lesilice's Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Lesilise Matembo, age 27, is married with 2 children (3 and 10 years old). Lesilise owns a cosmetics and clothing business, which she started 2 years ago. Working from 10am-4pm daily, she earns about $140 a month from this business.

Lesilise now hopes for a loan to purchase more cosmetics and clothing. Lesilise belongs to the loan group called Tumaini and will be sharing this loan with subgroup member Salama Muhumbe. Salama also sells clothing.

loans.use: To buy clothing and cosmetics stock

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Adham

texts.en: Adham is a 36 year old father of 2. He works and lives with his wife and children in south Lebanon, in Saida. Adham works in a bakery and needs a loan help him open his own bakery. He is determined to be professionally independent and to raise his living standards.

loans.use: To help him open his own bakery

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sunita M. is a shopkeeper in Tangal, Lalitpur. Tangal is one of the busiest towns in Lalitpur district. Most of the people in this region are engaged in business work. Mrs. Sunita lives in a single family home with her husband and two sons. Her husband Mr. Shrawan M. works in a garment factory. Her older son is in grade 2 and her younger son is only 2 years of age.

Mrs. M. opened her cosmetics shop 3 years ago. She sells different types of cosmetic goods in her shop like creams, lipsticks, glass bangles, etc. The demand for these types of goods is increasing in that area because of the wedding season. So she is requesting a Rs 15000 loan to buy cosmetic goods for her shop.

loans.name: Rukmani

texts.en:
Mrs. Rukmani T., 50 years old, is a tailor in the town of Tangal in Patan. She opened her tailoring shop 30 years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses and school uniforms for both boys and girls. She prefers to make popular dresses like Kurta Sulwar, blouses, ladies long dresses, Makhshi, and others.

Before starting her own business, Mrs. Tamarkar took a 6 month training course in tailoring when she was young. She plans to use the loan of Rs 15000 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to add to her family's income and support her children's education.

Her husband's name is Rabindra Kumar T.. However she is separated from her husband. She is solely responsible for the family. She has one son and two daughters. They are now studying.

loans.use: To buy raw material for her work

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
Carmen is an enterprising, married mother of two. She sells women's products, such as silver jewelry, undergarments, and cosmetics, among other beauty products. She has been involved in this field for over 6 years, and she now has a steady clientele who make special orders every week.

She tells us that thanks to this job, she can help her husband cover the household expenses, as well as her children’s educational expenses.

With this loan, she wishes to purchase silver jewelry such as necklaces, bracelets, rings, earrings, etc. as well as cosmetics and perfume. Her sales increased during the month of December, so she has been left practically without stock. She already has many orders for the month of February because people would like to offer her products as St. Valentine’s Day gifts.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Carmen, es una señora emprendedora, casada y madre de 2 niños. Carmen se dedica a la venta de artículos para damas como ser joyas de plata, ropas interior femenina, cosméticos, entre otros productos de belleza; esta actividad la lleva a cabo hace mas de 6 años y ya posee clientela fija que semanalmente le solicitan algún pedido especial.

Ella nos cuenta que gracias a este trabajo ella puede ayudar a su marido a cubrir los gastos de la familia y de la casa, como también los gastos de estudio de sus hijos.

Con el préstamos que solicita, ella desea comprar joyas como collares, pulseras, anillos, aretes, etc. de plata además de cosménticos y perfumes ya que durante los meses de diciembre y enero tubo muy buenas ventas y se ha quedado prácticamente sin stock. Este mes de febrero ya tiene muchos pedidos para regalo por día de San Valentín.

texts.es:

Ana owns a bookstore located in front of a school. Thanks to this optimum location, her sales are good. She sells all kinds of school supplies, fashion jewelry, and ice cream, among other items.

She is requesting this loan in order to buy more merchandise and start the school year offering students a greater variety of accessories.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Ana C. actualmente esta separada de su esposo tiene una hija de 4 años, quien es su mayor alegría.

Ana posee una librería que esta ubicada frente a un colegio, gracias a esto las ventas son bastante buenas. Ella vende todo tipo de útiles escolares, bijouterie, helados, entre otras cosas.

Ella solicita el crédito de tal forma que pueda comprar mas mercaderías para empezar este año con la mayor variedad de accesorios para los estudiantes.

loans.use: Purchase of school supplies such as: notebooks, backpacks, pencils, erasers, paintbrushes, etc.

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en: Rehema S. S., age 34, is married with 3 children (13, 7, and 3 years old) and 3 other dependents (ages 18, 20, and 12) who are also living with them. Rehema owns a soap and snack business, which she started 2 years ago. Rehema now hopes for a loan to buy more inventory of soap and chapati ingredients. Rehema belongs to the loan group called Furaha whose 20 members ensure that all pay back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more food ingredients and soap to sell

loans.name: Saidi's Pazi Group

texts.en:
Saidi Abdallah, age 43, is married and lives with her husband. Saidi owns a small general store, which she started 3 years ago. Working from 6am-7pm daily, she earns about $140 a month from this business.

In the past, Saidi successfully took out one previous loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a new loan to purchase more shop inventory. Saidi belongs to the loan group called Pazi and will be sharing this loan with subgroup members Fatuma H. and Fatuma J.. These women have businesses dealing in food vending and carpentry.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her shop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tiira Road C Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Sylvia N.. She is currently in the business of chacoal sales and is requesting a loan to expand the business. Sylvia is 30 years old and is married. Her husband repairs bicycles. She has 7 children ranging in age from 1.5 to 16, and 6 of them go to school. Each week, Sylvia makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits, and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Sylvia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Sylvia is joined in her small group by Scovia A., Jane A. and Jesca A.. Scovia A. has a business selling ripe bananas and wants to expand her business with the loan. Jane A. is currently operating a business selling matooke and wants a loan to add to her stock. Jesca A. also operates a business selling matooke and wants to expand it through a loan..

loans.use: To expand charcoal business

loans.name: Zuhura's Miafaka Group

texts.en:
Zuhura A., age 35, is single and owns a roadside café, which she started last year. Working from 6am-7pm daily, she earns about $25 a month from this business.

In the past, Zuhura successfully took out one previous loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a new loan to purchase more food stock (inventory). Zuhura belongs to the loan group called Miafaka and will be sharing this loan with another subgroup member Sophia S.. Sophia owns a shop.

loans.use: To buy food invetory for her cafe

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Please Delete Group

texts.en:
Kikwisa M., age 26, is married with 2 children (ages 7 and 4). She has a clothes and cosmetics business, which she started 2 years ago. Her business is open from 8am to 12 noon and from 4pm to 6pm daily ,making a monthly profit of about $52.

In the past Kikwisa, took out 1 previous loan with Tujijenge to increase on her business. She now hopes for a new loan to increase on the same business. She will share this loan with her sub group members who have businesses dealing in selling clothes, charcoal and foods.

In the picture Kikwisa is 1st fron left

loans.use: to increase on business

loans.name: Steven

texts.en: Steven is a 35 year old resident of Vituka area in Dar es Salaam. He runs a photo studio in Vituka area. He does video shooting and editing and gets paid for shooting on weddings and other parties in the area. He is currently in need of USD 600 to help him buy modern equipment for his job.

loans.use: BUY MODERN EQUIPMENT

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Youth Self Employment Foundation (YOSEFO) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 51 year old father of two, who lives with his wife and children in south Lebanon, in Tyre. Ali owns a grocery shop which is the main source of support for his family. In order to upgrade his family's living standards, Ali needs to expand his grocery business and thus requires a loan to buy new merchandise.

loans.use: To buy new merchandise

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Heleni

texts.en:
Heleni a 35-year-old mother of three lives in the Vituka area in the city of Dar es Salaam. She sells both used and new clothes in the Vituka trading center. She also operates a restaurant alongside the shop. She received training in business and entrepreneurship from the Youth Self Employment Foundation, which has helped her expand her business. 
Heleni requests a loan of $750 to purchase new and used clothing to sell in her shop.

loans.use: EXPAND STOCK

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Youth Self Employment Foundation (YOSEFO) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha does her business in Vituka area, a Dar Es Salaam city suburb.   She runs a shop selling both used and new clothes and bags; including school bags and ladies' bags. She has been doing business for the past 5 years and its has really improved her life.  She is now able to send her  two kids to school because of her increase in income. She is in need of USD $1200 to help her expand the business .

loans.use: EXPAND BUSINESS

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Youth Self Employment Foundation (YOSEFO) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Ajka

texts.en: Ajka was born in 1972 and she  lives in a small village called Seoci, near Zenica. Her husband has a full-time job as an ironworker. He earns about US$ 500 monthly. The  Mašić family has 2 children, 14 and 11 years old. Ajka is requesting a loan in the amount of  US$ 900 and she will use it for buying a cow, because she wants to  improve their monthly household income.

loans.use: Buying a cow

loans.name: Ferhada

texts.en: Ferhada is 19 years old and is not married. She lives in Vardi, a little village near Zenica. She re-sells clothes at the market. Ferhada wants to use this loan for purchasing additional clothing in order to improve her sales and increase her monthly income. She thinks this will  help her to find her niche at the market because she is new in this job.

loans.use: Purchasing  additional clothing for re-sale

loans.name: Natalya

texts.en:
Natalya D. is married with a daughter who is now grown-up Her family lives in Zaporozhye. Natalya sells clothing in the local market called Krytyi (Covered market). She offers affordable merchandise at reasonable prices and invests much time in the development of her business. Natalya currently has about $3000 in inventory. Her monthly net profit amounts to $600.

Natalya is requesting a loan of $1200 to help increase her sales and profits as a result. She is hoping to invest generated profits into the further expansion of her venture and open one more vending facility. We believe her responsible approach to business and this current financial assistance will be beneficial for Natalya’s business by keeping it competitive and promoting growth so that it will continue to provide necessary income for her and her family.

loans.use: To increase her profits

loans.name: Jose

texts.es:
Jose lives at his parents house on Muños Reyes street in the area of Calacoto in the city of La Paz. He is 21 years old and is a chef by profession. He studied at the Escuela Hotelera where he learned how to make national and international dishes, which has made him highly sought after. He has contracts for events every weekend, the earnings of which support him and pay for his studies. The loan he asks for is to buy a professional kitchen in order to serve his clients with greater ease. He does not have a prior history with our organization, but an analyses of his cash flow indicates that Jose will be able to pay monthly dues for the loan and at the same time cover his personal needs.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Jose vive en casa de sus padres en la calle Muños Reyes de la zona de Calacoto de la Ciudad de La Paz; tiene 21 años de edad y es Chef de profesión. Estudió en la Escuela Hotelera, lugar donde aprendió a elabora platos Nacionales e Internacionales, por lo cual es muy solicitado y tiene contratos para eventos cada fin de semana, con cuyos ingresos se mantiene y paga sus estudios. El crédito que solicita es para comprar una cocina profesional y así tener más facilidad para atender a sus clientes. No tiene antecedente histórico con nuestra Institución, pero el análisis de su flujo de caja indica que Jose podrá pagar las cuotas mensuales del préstamo y al mismo tiempo cubrir sus necesidades personales.

loans.use: Purchase a kitchen

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela is married with a 19-year-old son. She and her family live in Zaporozhye. Angela owns a small business in the central city market which is the biggest market in the neighborhood. She is a hard-working entrepreneur who has been in this trade for 11 years in a row. Presently, her turnover capital is about $900. 

Angela is hoping to use this loan of $1000 to increase her turnover capital and purchase assorted inventory wholesale. The quality clothing she offers for sale in her kiosk is always in demand among customers. Angela is hoping to re-supply her inventory and attract more clients offering an even better variety of merchandise this spring season. We believe Angela will benefit from more consistent financial support which will strengthen her trade and help her continue to grow professionally.

loans.use: To increase assorted inventory

loans.name: Ana

texts.es:
Mrs. Ana J. lives in her domestic partner’s grandparents’ house, located on 12 de Octubre Street in the Tembladerani sector of the city of La Paz. She has a 4-month-old baby. She sells fast food in the city of El Alto, where she rents a shop that opens only on Thursdays and Sundays, the days in which the markets operate.

She is requesting this loan in order to purchase wholesale goods such as rice, noodles, etc., thus lowering her expenses.

She does not have a credit history with Impro, but she qualifies for the loan because of her steady financial income.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Ana vive en casa de los abuelos de su concubino en la calle 12 de octubre de la zona de Tembladerani de la ciudad de La Paz; tiene un bebe de 4 meses, la actividad que realiza es la venta de comida en la ciudad de El Alto, lugar donde alquiló una tienda que funciona únicamente los días jueves y domingos, fechas en que se realizan las ferias.

El crédito que solicita es para comprar los insumos como ser arroz, fideo etc., al por mayor y de esta manera bajar sus costos.

No tiene antecedente con Impro pero califica para acceder a un crédito por el análisis de su flujo de caja.

loans.use: Purchase of rice, noodles, and other ingredients for the preparation of meals

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Genaro

texts.es:
Genaro lives in a house he owns on Inca Roca street in the area of Tacagua in the city of La Paz. He is 77 years old and has been a client of ours since 1999. He has used eleven loans with Impro and the business he runs is that of carpentry. He makes furniture by request, which is how he supports his needs since he does not have any other form of income. His preceding record qualifies him as a good client, thus giving him access to a new line of credit. All of his past loans have been paid fully and according to the dates established.

Translated from Spanish by Natalie Kane, Kiva Volunteer.

Genaro vive en casa propia en la calle Inca Roca de la zona de Tacagua de la ciudad de La Paz; tiene 77 años de edad y es cliente nuestro desde el año 1999; lleva once créditos con Impro y la actividad que realiza es la de carpintería: elabora muebles a pedido con lo cual sustenta sus necesidades ya que no tiene otro ingresos. El crédito que solicita es para la compra de material (Madera, Clefa, etc). Su antecedente histórico lo califica como buen cliente y puede acceder a un nuevo crédito. Todos los créditos anteriores han sido pagados en su totalidad y de acuerdo a las fechas establecidas.

loans.use: Purchasing materials (wood and others) for his carpentry business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more products for her general store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy a professional cutting machine and more fabrics

loans.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is married with two children. She is from Ivano-Frankivsk, Western Ukraine. Mariya owns a store in downtown Ivano-Frankivsk and sells children’s clothing and toys. Her business is well known for affordable prices and a good selection of merchandise. Mariya has been in this trade for 3 years. Presently, she has about $8000 in inventory. Her monthly income is around $1400 – 1600.  

Mariya is always on the run. She combines her entrepreneurial activity with a bookkeeping job for a small private firm. Mariya loves owning her business and is thinking about quitting her other job to commit herself fully to her entrepreneurial endeavors. She is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase assorted stuffed toys for further retail sale. Mariya is hoping to invest generated profits into the reconstruction of her private house.

loans.use: Increase assorted goods

loans.name: Zaenab

texts.en: Zaenab, 29, is married to I. and has 3 children. I. is a public transportation driver who earns a very small income. So to support her family, Zaenab opened a grocery store at her house where she sells snacks, household goods, etc., earning about $10 a day. She is requesting a loan of $100 to expand her business and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her little grocery store

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married with two teenage kids. She and her family live in Ivano-Frankivsk. Nataliya sells children’s clothing and footwear in two different locations – the central mall called “Prikarpattya” and a local market, “Troyan”, in downtown Ivano-Frankivsk. She originally started as a small market vendor. Today Nataliya offers a wide variety of prices and merchandise. She has been in business for 12 years and has 5 hired employees. Currently, she has about $16,000 in inventory. Her monthly income is about $2400.   

Nataliya would like to increase assorted merchandise in her second vending facility. She is hoping to continue working in this sphere of trade and generate additional income. That is why she is requesting a loan of $1000. Nataliya’s business is the only source of income for her family. She is trying hard to earn enough to pay for her kids’ college education and finish the reconstruction of her private house. We believe timely financial assistance will keep Nataliya’s business stable and her family well provided for.

loans.use: Increase assorted goods

loans.name: Kokoy

texts.en: Kokoy, 36, is married to S. and has 2 sons. She owns a little poultry business near her house. She raises the chickens and then sells them, earning about $75 a month, but she can not get a fixed income from this business. Her husband runs a workshop at their house and earns only a small income. So Kokoy needs a loan of $125 to expand her business and as a member of MBK she will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her little poultry business

loans.name: Lilis

texts.en: Lilis is a 43-year-old widow whose husband passed away a long time ago. So to earn a living for herself and her 2 children, she sells veils on credit door-to-door, earning about $6 a week. Now, to add to her business capital, she is asking for a loan of $100 so she can expand her business. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her little door-to-door sales business

loans.name: Nimah

texts.en: Nimah, 33, is married to A. and has 3 children. She has a pond where she raises fish and sells them once a week at the market. Sometimes she lets people fish in her pond. From this business she can earn on average $15 a week, but she cannot get regular income from it at present. Now she is asking for a loan of $100 to expand her business so she can get more income to cover her children's tuition. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Expansion of her fish farming business

loans.name: Anah

texts.en: Anah, 43, is married to N. and has 3 children. Her husband repairs flat tires for a living and earns about $3 a day with a small profit. So to support her family's needs, Anah opened a small shop at her house where she sells groceries and earns $15 a day. She has joined MBK and now she is asking for a loan of $100 to expand her shop. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To expand her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more products such as cosmetics, perfumes, and natural medicines

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue improving the products he has on inventory

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue investing in a variety of seafood

loans.name: Julian

texts.es:
Julian dedicates himself to providing transportation to the public; he relies on two vehicles, one of which he rents out while he drives the other, stationing himself at the taxi stand in Chapare. Julian has two daughters, aged 9 and 12. His wife also works, devoting herself to selling tablecloths at CANCHA.

Both have many years of experience in their lines of work, and both face stiff competition. What helps them out is that they are both affiliated with trade union representatives in their fields. These unions are well organized, and the demand for their services is high. Julian will use this request to complete the purchase of his vehicle, since the money he's making doesn't cover it. He has very good credit history, and his behavior with this institution was very good.

Translated from Spanish by Shannon Skoglund, Kiva volunteer.

Julian de dedica al transporte público, cuenta con dos movilidades de las cuales una la alquila y la otra la maneja ubicandose en la parada de taxis del Chapare. Julian tiene dos hijas que tienen 9 y 12 años de edad. Su esposa también trabaja dedicando al comercio de manteles en la CANCHA. Ambos tienen muchos años de experiencia en los rubros que se desempeñan y si bien la competencia en los mismos es bastante elevada lo que les fortalece es que son afiliados a Sindicatos representativos de sus rubros, estos sindicatos están bien organizados y paralelamente la demanda por estos servicios es también elevada. Esta solicitud, Julian la utilizará para completar la compra de un vehículo ya que el capital con el que cuenta no le alcanzó. Tiene muy buenos antecedentes crediticios y su comportamiento con la Institución fué muy bueno.

loans.use: Cash to finish paying off his car purchase.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación Agrocapital, a partner of ACDI/VOCA - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: America

texts.es:
America is a 46-year-old woman who dedicates herself to food sales. In the restaurant that she runs out of her home, she sells chicken, hamburgers, and other types of food at night. Her family is comprised of herself and her husband, who is her credit co-applicant; they do not have dependent children anymore. America has more than six years of experience in this business. She doesn't have a lot of competition in the area since there aren't many people selling food.
