She is asking for a loan in the amount of $1,200.00 to purchase merchandise and to make improvements to her store.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Maria tiene ya más de 2 años con su tienda de abarrotes. Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de mi familia. Me esta haciendo falta mas mercancía y mejorar el local para vender también lácteos y carnes frías. Solicito un préstamo de $1,200.00 Dlls. para la comprar de mercancía y mejorar el negocio.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and to make improvements to her store.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es:
Ms. B. has been earning a living selling meals for over a year. This business -- that she started out when she found herself alone with four children -- is the only source of income for her family. She is asking for a loan in the amount of $1000.00 to purchase more merchandise and utensils to prepare the food as well as some furniture.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Maribel tiene ya más de un año con su negocio de ventas de comida. Este negocio es la fuente de ingresos de mi familia. Empecé con este negocio cuando me quede solo y con mis cuatro hijos, pero nos esta haciendo falta mas mercancía para le elaboración de los platillos y mas inmobiliario. Solicitamos un prestamos de $1,000.00 Dlls para la comprar de mercancía y inmobiliario.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise and furniture

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Mansouratou

texts.fr:
Born on January 20, 1952 in COTONOU, the economic capital of BENIN, Ms. Mansouratou L. it married and a mother of 5 children. Being a baker for several years now, she also started the artisanal production of sweet bread three years ago. The high demand from her customers obliges her to increase her production, which is why she is asking for a loan to satisfy her customers' needs.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Née le 20 janvier 1952 à COTONOU capitale économique du BENIN , elle est mariée et mère de 5 enfants. Revendeuse du pain il y a quelques années, elle s’est lancée dans la fabrication artisanale du pain sucré depuis trois ans. La forte demande de sa clientèle l’oblige à accroître sa production d’où la nécessité de se référer à un crédit pour satisfaire sa clientèle.

loans.use: Purchase of 20 bags of corn flour and 5 caster sugar bags

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Alidé - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es:
I have an unfinished construction project in my house. I would like to raise a wall and add cement flooring but I have been unable to, due to lack of funds. I have plans to expand my house towards the front but it will have to be done little by little since it requires a large investment. I ask for $800 to raise a wall and lay cement flooring at my home.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

“Tengo una construcción sin terminar en mi vivienda, me gustaría poner una barda y piso de concreto pero no he podido por falta de recursos, tengo planes de ampliar hacia delante pero tendrá que ser poco a poco ya que se necesita una inversión mayor”. Solicito $ 800.00 dlls para construir una barda y poner piso de concreto en mi vivienda.

loans.use: To raise a wall and lay cement flooring.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Gloria

texts.es:
Driven by her love of cooking and the need to look after her five young children, two still of school age, Gloria opened a market food stall. There she makes ‘caldos’ (the name given to soups typical of her country) in the morning and also at lunch time. Gloria’s love of working doesn’t falter throughout the day, which is why she decided to also sell food at night from her home with the aim of generating more income, and thus being able to educate her children. With funding, she hopes to buy the necessary property to open a restaurant in her home and also buy a large stove. This way, she can improve service and generate more custom.

Translated from Spanish by Lucy Williams, Kiva volunteer

El gusto por la cocina y la necesidad de poder mantener a sus pequeños cinco hijos, dos aún en edad escolar. Gloria abrió un puesto de comida en el mercado. Ahí prepara “caldos” (denominación de una sopa típica en su país) en la mañana y también en la hora de almuerzo. Las ganas de trabajar de Gloria no merman al pasar del día, es por eso que ella, por otro lado, decidió también vender comida de noche en su casa con la idea de obtener más ingresos y poder educar a sus hijos. Lo que ella espera, de obtener un financiamiento, es comprar los inmuebles necesarios para abrir un restaurante en su casa y una estufa grande. De este modo, podría mejorar la atención y recibir más clientela.

loans.use: To complete improvements within her restaurant at home

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for EDAPROSPO - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Mario Alberto

texts.es:
"Several months ago I finished the construction of a room in the patio of my house, but I was unable to continue due to the lack of money. I am only missing to plaster the walls and finish the concrete roof in order to be able to inhabit this room which we dearly need". I am requesting a loan for $1,000 to plaster the walls and finish the roof.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


“Hace algunos meses termine la construcción de un cuarto en el patio de mi casa pero ya no pude continuar debido a que me falto dinero, ya solo me falta enjarrar las paredes y resanar la losa de concreto para poder habitar ese cuarto ya que nos hace mucha falta” Solicito $ 1,000.00 dlls para resanar la losa de un cuarto y enjarrar las paredes.

loans.use: Plaster walls and Roof Finishing / Resanar losa y enjarre de paredes

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
My wife and I have been able to expand our home -- which is our children's heritage -- with a lot of effort and hard work. Now we would like to lay the foundation to build a second story. However, this is a big investment and we are going to be short on money. I ask for $800.00 to lay the foundation to build a second story for my house.

Translated from Spanish by Libertad Leal, Kiva volunteer.

“Con mucho esfuerzo y trabajo mi esposa y yo hemos logrado ampliar nuestra vivienda ya que es el patrimonio de nuestros hijos, ahora nos gustaría empezar a preparar los cimientos para construir un segundo piso pero la verdad es un gasto fuerte y nos va a faltar dinero” Solicito $ 800.00 dlls para poner el cimiento y construir en la planta alta de mi casa.

loans.use: Lay the foundation to raise a second story for his house.

loans.name: Mouniratou

texts.fr:
Ms. L. Mouniratou was born on January 20, 1966 in COTONOU. A widow and a mother of 4 children, she manages a small company which produces and sells lollipops, yoghourt, ice cream and similar products. Her business is located in Yénawa, one of the most popular districts of Cotonou, which is a commercial area with demands growing day after day. She has thus decided to ask for a loan to satisfy her customers' requests.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Dame L. Mouniratou est née le 20 janvier 1966 à COTONOU. Veuve et mère de 4 enfants , elle est gérante d’une petite entreprise ayant pour activité principale la production et la commercialisation des sucettes, yaourt, glace et autres. Située à Yénawa l’un des quartiers les plus populaires de Cotonou qui est une zone bien située où la demande croît de jour en jour. Elle a donc décidé de faire recours au crédit pour satisfaire sa clientèle.

loans.use: Purchase of 20 bags of milk powder and 2 bags of sugar

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Alidé - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Gladyz

texts.es:
Gladys sells prepared meals, especially ceviche and seafood. Seven years ago, she started selling in the streets in a moving cart. As she acquired more clients and bigger earnings, she decided to rent a stand in the market and see what happened. Fortunately, thanks to her efforts, she has been doing very well in her small restaurant.

She states that she would not have thought of opening this business if it weren’t for some of her colleagues who she saw do well in similar businesses. Currently, she does not regret deciding to start from the bottom because she is certain that everything is possible with hard work. Her dream is to have a large restaurant, but for now she wants to expand her food stand.

Translated from Spanish by Evelyn Garcia, Kiva Volunteer.

Gladys se dedica a la venta de comida, especialmente Ceviche y mariscos. Hace siete años ella empezó con un puesto ambulante vendiendo en la calle, a medida que iba teniendo más clientes y más ganancias, ella optó por alquilar un puesto en el mercado y ver qué sucedía. Felizmente, gracias a su empeño, le ha ido bien en su pequeño restaurante.

Ella afirma que no se le hubiera ocurrido abrir este negocio de no ser porque veía que a algunas compañeras suyas les iba bien en negocios similares. En la actualidad, ella no se arrepiente de haberse decidido a empezar de abajo porque tienen la certeza de que con las ganas de trabajar todo se puede realizar. Su sueño es tener un restaurante grande, por ahora quiere ampliar su puesto.

loans.use: Expand her food stand.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for EDAPROSPO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Cristina

texts.en:
Cristina is a single mother of four school-going children.  She has been running a grocery store for five years in Café community of Santo Domingo.   Every day, people of the neighborhood visit her store to purchase  rice, milk, beans and other basic foodstuffs. 
Cristina explains that she hopes her business growth will help her buy her own house.  She is requesting a loan of $375 so she can buy more products to supply her grocery store and satisfy more of her customers' needs.

loans.use: To restock a small grocery store

loans.name: Yessica

texts.es:
"I've tried to make improvements to my home but in reality the economic situation is very tough. I already did the roof of a room and now I would like to install tile flooring to avoid rain water from collecting in front of my house. This causes humidity in the walls and hence diseases for my family" I am requesting $1,200 to put tile flooring in my house.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


“He tratado de hacerle mejoras a mi vivienda pero en realidad la situación económica esta muy difícil, ya le hice un techo de losa a un cuarto y ahora me gustaría poner vitropiso para evitar que el agua de las lluvias se junte en la entrada de mi casa, ya que esto provoca humedad en las paredes y por lo tanto enfermedades para mi familia”. Solicito $ 1.200.00 dlls para poner vitropiso en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Tile flooring my house / Poner vitropiso en mi vivienda

loans.name: Ndeye Fatou

texts.fr:
This is Mrs. T. second loan. Her business is at the large market in another village where she buys and resells smoked fish. This will allow her to help her husband with expenses for the children's education and the food.

Translated from French by Véronique Fourment, Kiva volunteer.

Madame T. est a son 2e pret ; son activite consiste a au grand marche d' un autre village pour acheter des poissons fumes et les revendre ; cela lui d ' aider son mari a entretenir l' education et la nourriture de ses 3 enfants .

loans.use: She is requesting a loan to buy raw materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Eneyda

texts.en:
Eneyda is the owner and operator of a beauty salon in Café community of Santo Domingo.  She has been running her business for eight months in order to support her four children's studies.  Eneyda humbly explains that her clientele is still limited, but she says she will keep working hard and offering a good-quality service so that she can attract new clients.
She is requesting a loan of $300 so she can buy a wiD. range of hair products to keep improving her business.

loans.use: To purchase product for a beauty salon.

loans.name: Salis Paola

texts.en:
Salis Paola is a young single mother of a three-year old daughter, and she lives in Altagracia community of Santo Domingo.  Shortly after her pregnancy, she was left alone by her partner, and since then she has been selling an assortment beauty products and perfumes by catalog to support herself and her child.
Currently, Salis has a loyal and growing clientele.  Sometimes she has to face payment delays from some customers, but generally the business is profitable. She has a monthly income of $100.00.
She is requesting a loan of $250 to purchase more products in and grow her business.

loans.use: To restock her inventory.

location.town: Altagracia VI Community, Santo Domingo N

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in seafood so he can distribute in larger quanities. (Invertir en mariscos al por mayor)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase accessories and products for her beauty salon

loans.name: Verónica Esperanza

texts.es:
"I own a small business in my house and I would like to invest in it to purchase more merchandise since it's missing several things. I also have plans to expand the store so that everything is well placed. But for now, I need to put together the capital for that which requires a greater investment". I am requesting $500 to invest in my business.

Translated from Spanish by Luis López Martinelli, Kiva Volunteer.


“Tengo un negocio pequeño en mi vivienda y me gustaría invertir en la compra de mercancía ya que me hacen falta muchas cosas, tengo planes de ampliar para que todo este más acomodado pero por lo pronto necesito juntar el capital para eso ya que se requiere de una inversión mayor”. Solicito $ 500.00 dlls para invertir en mi negocio

loans.use: Invest in my business / Invertir en mi negocio

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Leonardo

texts.es:
Leonardo is an electrician and does maintenance work in two buildings in the city of La Paz. This work is his main source of income and lets him support his son and wife. Leonardo lives in Zona de Río Seco in the city of El Alto.

The required credit will be used to purchase a computer which will serve Leonardo as a tool for his work. This is his first credit with Impro. The evaluation done shows that he is approved to receive this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Leonardo es electricista y realiza labores de mantenimiento en dos edificios de la ciudad de La Paz. Este trabajo es su fuente principal de ingreso y le sirve para cubrir la manutención de su hijo y esposa. Leonardo vive en la Zona de Rió Seco de la Ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito requerido será destinado para la compra de una computadora que le servirá como herramienta de trabajo.

Este es su primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada permite aprobar la solicitud del prestatario.

loans.use: Purchase of a tool for his work

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Ediccia

texts.es:
Villanueva is a village in Nicaragua in the city of Chinandega. This village is made up of different locales and municipalities with “El Obraje” being one of them, this being known as one of the more alienated ones with roads that are very hard to maneuver leading to it.

Because El Obraje is so hard to get to, its inhabitants do not receive electricity. This is the reason for Mrs. Ediccia E. B.’ request for the installation of a solar panel at her house which will improve her home situation. Upon the installation of the solar panel, Mrs. B. is responsible for the costs, and therefore is requesting a loan through Ceprodel to cover these expenses and provide the proper maintenance of the solar panel.

It is important to note that she is mother to three children that are in her care and the only support the family has is through her husband who works in agriculture and the raising of livestock. With the solar panel, Mrs. E. and her family can enjoy lighting in the evenings and access to a television.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Villanueva es un pueblo de Nicaragua ubicado en la ciudad de Chinandega. Este pueblo cuenta con diferentes localidades o municipios entre los que se encuentra “El Obraje” que se caracteriza por estar muy alejado y con difíciles caminos para transitar y llegar a esta localidad.

Debido a que El Obraje se encuentra muy alejado, los habitantes no cuentan con energía eléctrica es por esta razón que la señora Ediccia E. B. busca la manera de cómo mejorar la situación de su hogar y para ello solicita la instalación de un panel solar en su hogar de habitación. Al instalarle el panel, la señora B. queda en la obligación de cubrir esta deuda y es por esta razón que muy sabiamente ella acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con créditos que le permitan cancelar su deuda y darle el mantenimiento adecuado al panel.

Es necesario destacar que ella es madre de tres hijos a su cargo y el único sustento del hogar es su esposo que se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería en el mismo pueblo de Villanueva. Por medio del panel solar la señora E. y su familia puede gozar de iluminación por las noches y acceso a un televisor.

loans.use: Installation of a solar panel

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of solar panel

loans.name: Donald José

texts.es:
From a young age, Mr. Donald B. has devoted himself to the business of breeding cattle and agriculture, which supports his modest family. They live in the municipality of Obraje, which is in the city of Chinandega in Nicaragua.

A problem that Donald encounters is the lack of electric energy in his area since it is very far from the city. For this reason, he uses candles in the evenings but they only light up a small part of his home. To fix this situation, Donald has borrowed loans from Ceprodel to buy a solar panel. In this way, he can light up his home and have access to television for his family.

His greatest need is to pay off the debt used to buy a solar panel so he can continue to sustain his home and improve the standard of living for him and his family.

Translated from Spanish by Geraldine Kim, Kiva Translator.

El caballero Donald B. desde muy niño se dedica al negocio de la ganaderia agricultura siendo este su negocio con el que mantiene a su humilde familia que habita en el municipio el Obraje de la ciudad de Chinandega en Nicaragua.

Una problemática que atraviesa Donald es que en su localidad no existe energía eléctrica por estar muy lejos de la ciudad y por tal razón debe de alumbrarse por las noches con candelas que solamente iluminan una pequeña parte del hogar. Para erradicar esta situación, el señor Donald ha adquirido préstamos en Ceprodel para la adquisición de un panel solar y de esta manera poder alumbrar su hogar y tener acceso a un televisor para la familia.

Su mayor necesidad hoy en día es la urgencia de cancelar la deuda de este panel solar para así poder continuar manteniendo su hogar y mejorando su nivel de vida y el de los suyos.

loans.use: buy a solar panel

loans.name: Concepción

texts.es:
Concepcion is a resident of the village El Obraje in the city of Chinandega in Nicaragua. She is married, a mother and a housewife. Her husband works in agriculture on a small scale.

The problem that Mrs. Concepcion faces is that her village does not have electricity due to the fact that it is so far removed. This is the reason Mrs. Concepcion is requesting the installation of a solar panel in her home to improve her living conditions. To cover the costs she is requesting a loan from Ceprodel which will enable her to pay for the panel that she so needs. Having lights in her house will enable her to better carry out the work and duties in her home. In spite of her difficult financial situation, she affirms that with the support from Ceprodel she will improve her home conditions and will be able to get ahead together with her family.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Concepción B. es una dama habitante del pueblo El Obrage de la ciudad de Chinandega en Nicaragua. Es madre casada y se dedica al trabajo de ama de casa. Su esposo se dedica a la agricultura desde muy pequeño.

La problemática que atraviesa la dama Concepción es que en su pueblo no cuentan con energía eléctrica por estar muy retirado de la ciudad. Por este motivo, la señora Concepción solicita la implementación de un panel solar para mejorar su situación de vida. Para cubrir esta deuda, muy inteligentemente acude a Ceprodel para obtener créditos que le permitan pagar el panel que le es de mucha utilidad por el hecho de que necesitan la luz eléctrica para realizar sus trabajos y quehaceres del hogar.

A pesar de su difícil situación económica, afirma que con el apoyo que le brinde CEPRODEL mejorara las condiciones de su hogar de habitación y además logrará salir adelante junto con su familia.

loans.use: Purchase of a solar panel

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Delia

texts.es:
Delia is a single mother. She has a five-year-old son who lives with her. Their house is located in Zona de Río Seco in the city of El Alto. Delia works as an elementary school teacher in the Bolivian Education System. The income she makes there isn't enough to cover her expenses, so she also makes aprons for cholitas (women of Andean dress that is traditional in Bolivia).

The required credit will be used to buy a sewing machine of medium quality, a tool that will let her generate more income.

This is the third credit offered by Impro to señorita T.. Because of the evaluation of her previous loans, it has been concluded that she is approved for this one.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Delia es madre soltera, tiene un hijo de 5 años de edad y vive con su madre; su domicilio esta ubicado en la Zona de Río Seco de la Ciudad de El Alto. Trabaja en el Magisterio como profesora del nivel primario del Sistema Educativo Boliviano, los ingresos percibidos por dicha ocupación no son suficientes para cubrir sus gastos, por lo que también se dedica a la confección de mandiles para cholitas (mujér de vestimenta andina, típica de Bolivia).

El crédito requerido es para comprar una maquina de costura de mediana calidad, herramienta que le permitirá generar mayores ingresos.

Este es el tercer crédito otorgado por Impro a la señorita T.. Debido a la evaluación de sus antecedentes, se concluye la aprobación de su solicitud.

loans.use: Purchase of work material

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Dominga Del Socorro

texts.es:
Doña Dominga is a strong woman who has supported her husband for eight years by making and selling corn tortillas and beans in her humble home. They are a family of scare economic resources. Her work is tiring because she gets up at 5:00 in the morning and goes to bed at 9:00 at night because she strives to pay some of their home's expenses.

The products that Dominga makes in her home are consumed daily by the neighboring homes in her community because they represent basic food stuffs for poor families. Dominga's husband works as a security guard and pays for the rest of the home's expenses. This credit will be used to construct a room for their son. Right now all three of them sleep in the same room. With this money, they will be able to buy cheap materials to construct a room for their son.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Doña Dominga es una mujer esforzada que desde hace 8 años apoya a su esposo elaborando y vendiendo tortillas de maíz y frijoles cosidos en su humilde vivienda, son una familia de escasos recursos económicos, su trabajo es cansado se levanta a las cinco de la mañana hasta las nueve de la noche con este esfuerzo ha podido suplir ciertos gastos de la casa.

Los productos que la señora elabora en su casa son consumidos diariamente en los hogares aledaños de su comunidad, ya que representan la alimentación básica de las familias pobres. El esposo de la señora trabaja como guarda de seguridad y es quien complementa todos los gastos de la casa. La solicitud del crédito de esta pareja es la de construirle un cuarto a su hijo, en vista que actualmente duermen los tres en la misma habitación, con ese dinero podrán con materiales baratos construirle a su hijo.

loans.use: To buy bricks, cement, sand, and iron to construct a room

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Francisco Javier

texts.es:
Francisco, 40, is married and has one 12-year old son who is in 6th grade. His wife is a homemaker and cares for their son. This small family lives in the Memorial Sandino settlement, a neighborhood where people have few resources. Many of the people of the neighborhood work as street vendors, selling their products in other parts of the city, at markets and street corners.

So it is that Francisco has earned a living, working as a street vendor for the last 12 years, selling cosmetics and men's and women's clothing at good prices in order to be able to take money home at the end of each day. He begins his day at 6 in the morning and doesn't get home until 6 at night, every day of the week. Francisco now hopes to buy new merchandise including children's clothing which is in high demand and the product that sells fastest.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Don Francisco tiene 40 años de edad, casado, con un hijo de 12 años de edad, el cual cursa 6to grado de primaria, su esposa se queda en casa realizando los oficios del hogar y cuidando al niño. Esta pequeña familia habita en el asentamiento Memorial Sandino, en donde los pobladores de este sector son de escasos recursos económicos y muchos de ellos salen de sus viviendas a vender sus productos de manera ambulantes a otros barrios, mercados y semáforos de la ciudad.

Es así como se gana la vida Don Francisco, un hombre que desde hace 12 años se dedica a esta actividad, vende cosméticos y ropa para dama y caballeros a precios favorables con el propósito de llevar dinero diario a casa, inicia su día de trabajo a las 6:00 am y llega a las 6: 00 pm, todos los días de la semana. En estos momentos el sr. Desea comprar mercadería y diversificar el producto comprando ropa de niños que le están demandando y es lo que más se vende con rapidez.

loans.use: Buy products for resale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Lesbia Esther

texts.es:
Lesbia is a married woman with two school-aged children. She's a native of Villanueva in the "departamento" of Chinandega in the beautiful country of Nicaragua. For 9 years, she's worked as a preschool teach in order to support her humble home and educate her children. Lesbia has long faced the need to invest in her house which is in a poor state of repair. She is applying to Ceprodel for a loan so that she can fund the improvements.

Lesbia has already begun the improvements with loans she's received from Ceprodel but she needs more funds to continue. She's applying to Ceprodel again, confident that she will benefit from the loans and fulfill her dream to provide her children with a fit place to live.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Lesbia Esther S. es una dama casada y con dos niños en edad escolar. Es originaria de Villanuenueva en el departamento de Chinandega de la bella nación de Nicaragua. Desde hace 9 años se desempeña como docente de preescolar para lograr mantener su humilde hogar y darle la educación a sus hijos. Una problemática que por mucho tiempo ha atravesado la señora Lesbia es la necesidad de invertir en su casa ya que ha estado en malas condiciones. Por esta razón es que acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con créditos que le permitan invertir en la construcción de su hogar.

Hoy en día con los créditos que Ceprodel le ha brindado ha iniciado con la construcción de su casa pero aun le falta continuar por lo que muy confiadamente acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con lo créditos y de esta manera llegar a lograr su sueño de brindarle a sus hijos un techo digno donde poder vivir.

loans.use: House repairs.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Donald Rogelio

texts.es:
Donald is a welder and electrician, with more than 20 years experience. He works from home, making metal railings, steel-framed windows and supports for porches and houses, among other things. He works every day from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening.

He has a broad customer base that includes single orders from individuals along with private companies that hire him for temporary jobs. He is the sole provider for his family. His wife cares for their 2 young children. His work has allowed him to provide a humble living for all of them. His priority now is to lay new floors in the living room and the children's room, both of which have been damaged by time and use.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

El Sr. Donald es de profesión soldador y electricista industrial, posee 20 años de experiencia en esta rama, trabaja a domicilio, se dedica a elaborar verjas, ventanas de hierro, remodelar habitaciones y soldar perlines para porches y viviendas. Se encuentra disponible todos los días de 7:00 a.m. a 6:00p.m.

Posee un buen número de clientes tanto personas particulares como empresas privadas que lo contratan de manera temporal. El es el único proveedor de su familia, la esposa cuida de sus 2 hijos menores de edad. Su trabajo le ha permitido mantener a su familia humildemente, la prioridad en estos momentos es la de cambiar el piso del cuarto de los hijos y la sala de su vivienda, ya que se encuentran dañados de tanto tiempo y uso.

loans.use: Buy materials for home improvements.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Daniel

texts.es:
Daniel owns a service shop for public transportation vehicles, which is his only source of income. His staff consists of three employees. Daniel supports his young four-year-old son and his wife. His house is located in the Luiz Espinal zone in the city of El Alto.

The credit will be used to purchase materials for the shop like springs, hydraulic liquids, and other items.

This is Daniel's first credit with Impro. The evaluation done means that he has been approved for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer

Daniel posee un taller de servicio (su única fuente de ingreso) para vehículos particulares y de servicio público, asimismo, su personal consta de 3 empleados. Daniel mantiene a su pequeño hijo de 4 años y a su esposa. Su domicilio esta ubicado en la Zona Luis Espinal de la ciudad de El Alto.

El crédito requerido será destinado a la compra de materia prima para el taller. Por ejemplo muelles, líquidos hidráulicos y otros.

Este es su primer crédito con Impro. La evaluación realizada permite aprobar la solicitud del prestatario.

loans.use: Purchase of materials

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for IMPRO - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Rosa Adelaida

texts.es:
Rosa is a single mother with a young son. For 8 years, she's been a teacher at a small school in the Nicaraguan town of Villanueva. The difficult economic situation that Rosa faces is how to support a household on her meager income and still provide her son with an education. She's succeeded in improving her standard of living, thanks to the loans she's received from Ceprodel, starting construction work on her house that has for some time been in a poor state of repair.

Her major requirement now is to continue improving her house. She's looking forward to the future with confidence because she expects the Ceprodel loans to help her complete the work on her house and keep her little family together.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Rosa Adelaida S. es una madre soltera y con un pequeño hijo a su responsabilidad que desde hace 8 años se dedica a la docencia en un pequeño colegio del pueblo Las pilas en Villanueva de Nicaragua. La difícil situación económica que por mucho tiempo ha atravesado la señora Rosa Adelaida ha dado lugar a que busque la manera de cómo subsistir y a pesar de sus bajos ingresos ha logrado mantener su hogar y brindarle la educación a su hijo. Hoy en día la señora Rosa ha mejorado su nivel de vida gracias a los créditos que le ha brindado Ceprodel por lo que ha iniciado la construcción de su hogar que por mucho tiempo se ha encontrado en malas condiciones.

Su mayor necesidad hoy en día es continuar con la construcción de su vivienda y según comenta se siente muy confiada ya que espera ser beneficiada con los créditos de Ceprodel para lograr construir su casa y seguir manteniendo su núcleo familiar.

loans.use: House repairs and improvement.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Jesús Ramiro

texts.es:
Jesus is a strong man, having spent his life raising farm animals. He has 5 children, including two in primary school and two in high school. He's a native of the town of Las Pilas de Villanueva in the beautiful country of Nicaragua. Despite his difficult economic situation, he's managed to provide for his children's schooling and they, in turn, even at their young ages, help him with his back-breaking work.

Jesus urgently needs to buy a pregnant cow in order to continue his business. He applied to Ceprodel for a loan to purchase the cow so that he can maximize his income and support his family, giving his children the education that they so richly deserve.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Jesús B. es un caballero muy esforzado debido a que toda su vida la ha dedicado al trabajo con el ganado. Actualmente tiene 5 hijos a su cargo de los cuales cuatro de ellos están en edad escolar dos cursando la primaria y dos cursando la secundaria. Es originario del pueble Las Pilas de Villanueva de la bella nación de Nicaragua. A pesar de su difícil situación económica ha logrado apoyar a sus hijos en sus estudios quien a sus cortas edades también se dedican a apoyar a su padre en este arduo negocio.

La necesidad que atraviesa el señor Jesús B. es la urgencia de adquirir una vaquilla preñada para continuar con su negocio. Para esto acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiado con créditos que le permitan adquirir esta vaquilla y así sacarle el máximo provecho para continuar manteniendo su núcleo familiar y brindándoles la educación a sus hijos que tanto se la merecen.

loans.use: Buy new stock.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Claudia Del Socorro

texts.es:
Like many women, Claudia works to help her husband with household expenses. She works 12 hours a day, with only short breaks, as a textile operator at a factory in a free-trade zone, laboring to meet her employer's daily production targets. Her husband is a cab driver. Their humble house is in need of repairs. Specifically, they need to replace their zinc roof because some years ago, they bought used zinc panels for the roof and the rain and sun have damaged it, leaving it split. They're afraid for their children and the house.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Como muchas mujeres la Señora Claudia G., para ayudar a su esposo en los gastos de su hogar trabaja como operaria textil de una zona franca, trabajando 12 horas diarias, con un tiempo mínimo de descanso en una maquila con un numero de piezas a elaborar diariamente establecido por su empleador, su esposo trabaja como taxista. Su humilde vivienda necesita de una mejora y es la e cambiar el zinc del techo de su vivienda, ya que hace varios años habia comprado zinc usado y el sol y la lluvia lo dañaron, encontrandose rajado y teme por la seguridad de sus hijos y su casa

loans.use: Buy materials to repair roof of house.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Blacina Amanda

texts.es:
Blacina is a native of the borough of Villanuevo in the Nicaraguan city of Chinandega. For 3 years, she's operated a small general store that she set up in a room of her house. She's a single mother of a son and she drives herself hard every day to make sure that he's healthy, able to go to school and safely housed.

The business was born when Blacina realized that her old business, raising and selling farm animals, wasn't providing enough income. She decided to invest her small savings in opening the store. Thanks to the loans provided by CEPRODEL, she's managed to improve both her business and her young son's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

Blacina T. es una dama originaria del municipio de Villanueva de la ciudad de Chinandega de Nicaragua. Se dedica desde hace 3 años al negocio de pulpería el cual está ubicado en su casa de habitaron. Es madre soltera y con la responsabilidad de un hijo el cual es el motivo para que se esfuerce cada día mas para brindarle salud, educación y un techo digno donde habitar.

El negocio nace cuando se da cuenta que su antiguo negocio de ganadería no le cubría para sus necesidades por lo que decide invertir sus pocos ahorros en los productos de la pulpería. Hoy en día gracias a los créditos que le ha brindado CEPRODEL ha logrado mejorar su negocio surtiendo sus productos y a su vez ha mejorado la condición de vida de su pequeño hijo.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Gavino Marcelino

texts.es:
Gavino works as a tailor, making and repairing clothes for men, women and children. He's operated his business for 4 years during which he's perfected his skills with each stitch. He works in his house and his customers are mostly office workers who order skirts, pants and blazers. He learned to use a sewing machine at a very young age and he's passionate about his work. He works every day from 7 in the morning to 8 in the evening.

He's applying for a loan so that he can buy different kinds of cloth and especially cloth for making school uniforms. The new school year will start soon and making uniforms is a good way to capture new customers.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Vounteer

El señor Gavino se dedica a la sastrería en donde confecciona y repara ropa para damas, caballeros y niños, lleva 4 años en esta actividad, tiempo en el cual ha podido perfeccionarse en cada prenda que elabora, trabaja en su vivienda, sus clientes son mayormente oficinista que requieren que le elabore faldas, pantalones y bleizer. Este oficio le apasiona mucho, desde muy joven aprendió el uso y manejo de la maquina de coser, él atiende a sus clientes de 7:00am a las 8:00pm., todos los días.

El señor solicita un préstamo para comprar telas de diferentes tipos en especial para uniformes escolares en vista que los colegios iniciaron sus clases y esta época es buena para su negocio lo que le ayuda a captar clientes.

loans.use: Buy materials for tailoring business.

loans.name: Lucy Aurora's Group

texts.en:
Lucy, Yolanda, and Luz are members of the community bank “Triunfo II”. Lucy and Luz have been members for over ten years while Yolanda joined one year ago. In that time they have learned responsibility and how to increase their business. They have also learned about health and how to improve their relationships with their husbands.

Lucy is 37 years old. She is married and has five children between the ages of three and twenty-three. Lucy has owned a tailor shop for ten years. She began working out of her home but now rents a store. Before this she raised and butchered animals.

Yolanda is 25 years old. She grows flowers in the nearby small town of Quinua and then sells them at the in Ayacucho. She has had this business for five years. Since joining the community bank Yolanda has been able to open a store where she sells both flowers and food staples such as rice, sugar, and flour.

Luz travels to different markets in the region buying fruits, vegetables, and grains, she then sells them in the city of Ayacucho. On weekends she uses her car to transport passengers between various small towns.

Lucy, Yolanda, and Luz need loans of 400, 1000, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use in addition to their savings to buy an industrial sewing machine, a larger car, and to generally increase their level of merchandise.

Their dreams are to be millionaires and failing that to continue to develop their businesses, give their children a better life, own a nice house with two floors, and a car.

loans.use: Lucy, Yolanda, and Luz need loans of 400, 1000, and 400 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use in addition to their savings to buy an industrial sewing machine, a larger car, and to generally increase their level of merchandise.

loans.name: Miguel

texts.es:
For more than 12 years, Miguel has worked as an educator, teaching primary school-aged children at the Rene Shick State School, at a monthly salary of approximately US$130. For him, teaching is a labor of love and a way to shape his community's children.

Since his salary doesn't stretch very far or even cover basic expenses for providing food and clothing for his family, Miguel works evenings, three to five times a week, as a chauffeur. It pays enough to help him provide for his wife and young daughter.

The purpose of this loan is to improve and enclose the kitchen of his small and humble house which is very run down. Miguel doesn't have the resources to finish the kitchen but with your help he hopes to go on improving his family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

El señor Miguel Ángel desde más de 12 años trabaja como Maestro enseñando a niños de primaria en el Colegio Estatal Rene Shick, con un salario mensual aproximadamente de ciento treinta dólares (U$130.00) mensuales, su oficio es un desempeño de amor y entrega a la formación de los niños de su comunidad.

En vista que su humilde salario no le cubre para la totalidad de sus necesidades ni alcanza para cubrir la canasta básica de alimentos ni vestuario de sus familias, este Maestro trabaja por las tardes como chofer de una casa particular de tres a cinco veces por semana, con lo cual se ayuda para completar las necesidades de su familia conformada por su esposa e hija pequeña.

El objeto de este crédito es la de mejorar y cerrar la cocina de su pequeña y humilde vivienda, la cual se encuentra en malas condiciones y por la falta de recursos económicos no ha podido continuar la construcción de su cocina, pero con su esfuerzo desea ir mejorando la calidad de vida de su familia.

loans.use: Buy building materials to improve kitchen.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for AFODENIC - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Victoriano Antonio

texts.es:
Manufacturing and selling bricks for construction is a business that requires a lot of effort and skill to be successful. Victoriano has earned a living at it for 20 long years in the Nicaraguan town of Villanueva.

Victoriano is married and has three school-age children. He works hard to make sure that his children are provided for and that whatever he has goes to support his humble home. To support his business, Victoriano needs to buy raw materials like clay and sand. He's applying to Ceprodel for funds to help him buy the materials he needs to continue his business.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

El negocio de la elaboración y venta de tejas para la construcción es un negocio muy fuerte que requiere de mucho esfuerzo y agilidad para llevarlo a cabo. El señor Victoriano R. se dedica a este negocio desde hace 20 largos años en el pueble de Villanueva en la ciudad de Chinandega de Nicaragua.

Actualmente es casado y con tres hijos en edad escolar. Asegura que el mayor de sus esfuerzos los realiza para continuar manteniendo a sus hijos y llevando el sustento a su humilde hogar. Para llevar a cabo esta actividad, el señor Victoriano requiere de la compra de materia prima como barro, arenilla y tierra. Es por esta razón que acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiado con créditos que le beneficien en la adquisición de su materia prima para continuar son su negocio.

loans.use: Buy raw materials for brick-making business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Delia Luz's Group

texts.en:
Delia and Florenta have been members of the community bank “Imasumac” for thirteen and fourteen years respectively. In that time they have learned how to improve their businesses, save, be responsible, and to see the other associates as sisters.

Delia is 52. She is married and has one adult child. She sells clothing and cosmetics. Delia takes orders and then travels ten hours to the city of Lima to buy them. She has had this business for ten years.

Florenta is 50 years old. She is married and has three children. Florenta sells vegetables as well as auto parts. She works at the vegetable market in the morning and then sells car parts from a different market in the afternoon. She has been selling auto parts for two years, but started selling vegetables with her mom when she as twelve.

Delia and Florenta need loans of 1000 and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in their businesses.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has Delia and Florenta plant o use their savings to buy a car within the next year, and to open a store this July. Their dreams are to continue growing and improving their lives, as well as to help their children to become professionals

loans.use: Delia and Florenta need loans of 1000 and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will invest in their businesses.

loans.name: Lindsay

texts.en:
Lindsay is 26 years old. She is a single mother with a seven-year-old son. She joined the community “Imasumac” bank three years ago after being encouraged by a friend. In the bank she has received support and learned how to run her businesses more efficiently.

Lindsay has three businesses. She sells “caña”, an alcohol made from sugar cane, she sells food staples such as flour, rice and sugar, and in addition she travels nine hours once every two weeks to buy clothing in Lima that she then sells in Ayacucho. Lindsay has been selling food staples and clothing for two years, but only recently started selling caña. She now has three stores where she distributes the alcohol.

Lindsay needs a loan of 2500, soles which she will use to expand her caña business.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Lindsay plans to use her savings to buy a car. Her dream is to eventually have a large grocery distribution center, and to start buying caña directly from the producers in northern Peru.

loans.use: Lindsay needs a loan of 2500, soles which she will use to expand her caña business.

loans.name: Juana's Group

texts.en:
Juana, ClotilD., and Fernandina are members of the community bank “Imasumac”. Juana and Fernandina have belonged for ten years, while ClotilD. joined two years ago. In that time they have learned to be responsible, punctual, and to save. In addition they are now friends with the other associates in their bank.

Juana is 60 years old. She is married and has seven children. One of her daughters has been living in Miami for the last seven years. Juana buys vegetables in the countrysiD. and sells them in Ayacucho. She also has a business washing laundry.

ClotilD. is 25 years old. She lives with her partner and three year old son. ClotilD. is a trained nurse but cannot find work in that field. Currently ClotilD. runs a business typing forms and doing computer design. She has been running this business for the past three years.

Fernandina is 43 years old. She is married and has three children between the ages of 24 and 11. Fernandina sells vegetables. She buys vegetables in bulk in the city of Ayacucho and then sells them around the region. She has been doing this since she was fifteen years old.

Juana, ClotilD., and Fernandina need loans of 450, 1500, and 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy vegetables such as squash, carrots, and onions. ClotilD. will buy a new printer.

One of the most important things about the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Juana, ClotilD., and Fernandina plan to use their savings to open a stO. in their house, get a passport to travel to Brasil and work as a nurse, and to put a roof on their home. Their dreams are to build a house for their daughter so she will come back from Miami, own a nice home, and to have a big stO. in their home.

loans.use: Juana, Clotilde, and Fernandina need loans of 450, 1500, and 1000 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy vegetables such as squash, carrots, and onions.  Clotilde will buy a new printer

loans.name: Nancy Magaly

texts.en:
Nancy has been a member of the community bank “Suni” for four years. In that time she has learned to be responsible, disciplined, and to save. Nancy works in the country and attends meetings monthly instead of weekly. She likes this arrangement and is happy that the community bank was able to work with her to find a plan that worked

When Nancy first joined the community bank she sold the vegetables that her in-laws grow in their garden. Now she and her husband have been able to buy a motorcycle taxi and start a business selling motor oils and candies at a gas station. Nancy needs a loan of 2500 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying a greater variety of motor oils.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earnings savings account each associate has. Nancy plans use her savings to build a house. Her dream is to be able to have a farm and raise animals.

loans.use: Nancy needs a loan of 2500 soles (3 soles = $1), which she will invest in buying a greater variety of motor oils.

loans.name: María Teresa

texts.en:
María Teresa is forty-four years old, and she is the mother of five children.  María Teresa lives in Hortaliza community of Santo Domingo.
María explains that currently she needs funds to support her children's studies, and her husband’s salary (he is a policeman) is not enough to bear all the family’s expenses.  Therefore, she plans on starting a small cafeteria in her house.  She says she will sell fried food, spaghetti, sausage pork and natural juices.  María Teresa has a huge experience in food preparation, which will help her business be successful.
She is requesting a loan of $225 to purchase the necessary goods to start the cafeteria.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to start a small cafeteria.

loans.name: María Antonia

texts.en:
María Antonia is twenty-seven years old, and she and her husband have five children, three of them boys that attend school.  María Antonia has been a money lender for more than two years.  “This is the way I can help the neediest people of the neighborhood”, she says.  She and her husband work, and they put asiD. part of their salary to lend people.
María Antonia hopes that someday she’ll have a house and enough money to improve her family's living conditions.  She is requesting a loan of $375 to invest in her loan business so that she can keep changing her neighbors’ lives.

loans.use: To invest in a small money-lending activity for the sake of people of her hometown.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia, a twenty-four year old mother of three children, lives in Casabe community of Santo Domingo where she strives to make a living and support her family.
She helps needy people of her hometown by lending them money at very low interests.  Patricia explains that the most of people of Casabe don’t have a job.  And people that work receive their salary bi-weekly, but they have to spend money every day to face the household issues.   Her clientele is built-up of these people.
Her husband, a truck driver, helps her run the business.  Patricia says that she wants to turn her business into a formal lending bank with lots of customers.  “My neighbors need help, and as far as possible, I will help them”.  She is requesting a loan of $375 so that she can have more capital to keep running her business.

loans.use: To invest in her small money-lending house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Set up a fish-selling store in their home.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase Oven

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase merchandise and make improvements to her shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of more merchandise and to make improvements to his store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more raw material

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more merchandise for the store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy a compressor for her workshop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more gas cylinders

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in raw materials

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in materials and supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy more merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Increase her inventory.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase fruit from a wholesaler.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Invest in more merchandise.

loans.name: Sunilda

texts.en:
Sunilda sells a variety of candies, cakes and pop corn to the children and teachers of primary school in Café community of Santo Domingo.  Sunilda has three school-going children, and she and her husband have to struggle in order to support their studies.
As she talks about her dream for the future, Sunilda says that she would like to have a house where her family can live comfortably.  She also wants to have a local place where she can operate the business. That way, Sunilda won’t have to take her merchandise everyday to the school, and people will be able to visit her store to make the purchase of these goods.
She is requesting a loan of $375 to buy raw materials to keep producing her candies and cakes.

loans.use: To purchase of raw materials to keep producing candies and cakes for her customers.

loans.name: Mercedes Lidia

texts.en:
Mercedes is fifty-six years old, and she and her husband have three sons.  Two of them go to the university.  Mercedes is a well-known teacher of a primary school in Café community of Santo Domingo.
As her husband is currently unemployed, and her salary is not sufficient to bear all the family’s expenses, Mercedes had to invest a part of her salary to buy of men’s clothing to resell in her community.
Although her activity has started recently, Mercedes has a lot of customers, most of them young people, who purchase her goods.
Mercedes is requesting a loan of $300 which she will use to expand her business, adding underwear to her inventory.  Mercedes hopes that her business expansion will help her improve her family’s living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase new goods to add to her inventory in order to diversify the offer.

loans.name: Elia María

texts.en:
Elia María is a multi-faceted and successful entrepreneur.  She lives with her three sons in Altagracia community of Santo Domingo.  Elia María sells an assortment of coco candies in her sister-in-law’s restaurant.  In the afternoon, she visits her friends and other neighbors to offer shirts, pants and shoes. She explains that she has to work hard in order to support her children’s studies and cover the household expenses.
She is requesting a loan of $375 to buy clothing in bulk to sell.  She will invest a small part of the money in the purchase of raw materials to produce her candies.

loans.use: Purchase clothing in bulk and other goods for another small business.

location.town: Altagracia VI Community, Santo Domingo N

loans.name: Altagracia Bienvenid

texts.en:
Altagracia Bienvenida, a forty-six year old woman, is the owner and operator of a small restaurant in Altagracia community of Santo Domingo.  She has been running the restaurant for four years, and now she has a well established clientel.  The customers are very satisfied with the tasteful meals and juices the cook prepares, and they love her for her sympathy and hearty laugh.
Altagracia’s restaurant has a very effective take-out service.  Every day, she serves more than seventy plates to take to her customers' houses, and a lot of people visit her restaurant to get her delicious food.
This businesswoman, mother of three children, is requesting a loan of $400 to buy raw materials, disposable plates and plastic cups to keep business running smoothly.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials and other goods to keep producing food for her small restaurant.

location.town: Altagracia VI Community, Santo Domingo N

loans.name: Igamba East C Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Betty K.. She runs a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase the stock in the shop. Betty is 42 years old, and married with 4 children, ranging from age 12 to 18. Her husband Her children all go to school.

Each week, Betty makes approximately 17000 UGX profit. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to invest in growing and selling maize. In the past, Betty had a loan of 200000 UGX from BRAC Uganda , which she used to increase the stock in her shop. She paid back the loan on time.

Betty is joined in her small group by Khadija Nantambi, Amina B., Joweria Nakawoma, and Judith N.. Khadija Nantambi sells matooke, charcoal, and tomatoes, and wants to increase her charcoal business. Amina B. is currently selling clothes and ladies shoes and wants a loan to increase the inventory of shoes and clothes. Joweria Nakawoma operates a local cinema hall and wants to buy a bigger generator and more fuel to improve the business. Judith N. currently has a local brewing business and is requesting a loan to start trading sugar at the wholesale market.

loans.use: To increase the stock in retail shop

loans.name: Narirurwe West A Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Hadija N.. She currently has a butcher shop and is requesting a loan to set up more butcher shops. Hadija is 48 years old, and married. Her husband has a butcher shop and also trades animal skins. She has 12 children ranging in age from 8 to 24, and 6 of them go to school.

Each week, Hadija makes approximately 20000 UGX (approximately $11.00) profit. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to trade more bags of charcoal. Previously, Hadija had a loan from BRAC Uganda 100000 UGX in order to set up a butcher stall, and the loan was paid back on time.

Hadija is joined in her small group by Zam Nabiryo, Joweria N., Hanifa N., and Margret G.. Zam Nabiryo sells used clothes and wants to get a permanent place to conduct business. Joweria N. currently is operating a business selling used clothing and wants a loan to purchase more bags of clothes to sell. Hanifa N. has a retail shop and wants to increase the stock in her shop. Margret G. is currently raising cattle and selling charcoal, and is requesting a loan to buy more Friesian cows.

loans.use: To open more butcher shops

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her used clothing business

loans.name: Narirurwe West C Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Aisha N.. She currently has a business selling clothing. She is requesting a loan to increase the inventory of clothes to sell. Aisha is 33 years old and is married. Her husband has a butcher shop. She has 4 children ranging from ages 6 to 18 and her children go to school.

Each week, Aisha makes approximately 350000 UGX (about $205) profit. With the extra profit gained from increasing the clothing sales, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Aisha has had a loan for 100000 UGX (about $60) from BRAC Uganda in the past in order to invest in her business, and the loan was paid back on time.

Aisha is joined in her small group by Habiba N., Zawija Biriabwa, Rose K., Lukia N., and Harriet N.. Habiba N. has a talioring business and wants to set up a shop selling clothes. Zawija Biriabwa has a butcher shop and sells the meat, and wants a loan to buy more animals for slaughtering. Rose K. has a retail shop and wants to increase the stock. Lukia N. currently has a tailoring business and is requesting a loan to buy more sewing machines. Harriet N. sells charcoal and intends to purchase more sacks of charcoal from villages.

loans.use: To increase clothing sales

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more used clothes for resale

loans.name: Nakururwe West D Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is N. K.. She has a drug shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs to sell. N. is 37 years old and is single. She has 6 children ranging in age from 5 to 18, and 4 of her children go to school. Each week, N. makes approximately 70000 UGX (about $40) profit and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up another restaurant. N. has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 1800000 in order to invest in business and the loan was paid back on time.

N. is joined in her small group by Zainah T., Mariamu N., B. Faridah, and Faridah B.. Zainah T. has a business in selling clothes and wants to increase the stock of clothes. Mariamu N. runs a restaurant and wants a loan to buy a fridge and more food warmers. B. Faridah sells charcoal and wants to increase the stock of charcoal. Faridah B. has a tailoring business of and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase more drugs for sale and expand business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase her stock of clothing for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her shoe business

loans.name: Narirurwe West B Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Jamawa K.. She has a retail shop and is requesting a loan to increase the stock in the shop. Jamawa is 29 years old and is married. Her husband has a butcher shop. She has 4 children ranging in age from 3.5 to 13 and only 2 of them go to school.

Each week, Jamawa makes approximately 70000 UGX (about $40) profit. She is requesting a loan so that she can earn more money to be able to buy a weighing scale. In the past, Jamawa had a loan from BRAC Uganda for 100000 UGX (about $60) in order to invest in business and the loan was paid back on time.

Jamawa is joined in her small group by Fatina B., Sisirsa K., Aidah N., Fazira N., and Safina Nangobis. Fatina B. has a grocery store and wants to increase the inventory. Sisirsa K. is currently selling sugarcane and wants a loan to purchase more sugarcane to sell. Aidah N. operates a retail shop and wants to buy more items to sell. Fazira N. runs a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to increase the oils and other items for sale in the salon. Safina N. sells charcoal and wants to use the loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To add more stock in the retail shop

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her clothing business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand his business selling green maize

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more polythene bags for sale

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima H. is 30 years old and a married mother of 3. She operates a food stall in the local market and plans to use her Kiva loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To develop her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Motomoto Group

texts.en: Sofia K. is the leader of this loan group. She is 32 years old and single with 2 children. She plans to use her Kiva loan to develop and expand her food stall.

loans.use: To develop her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Furaha Group

texts.en: Anna M. is 43 years old and the mother of 2. Her main aim is to increase her working capital and provide her children with a better life.

loans.use: To expand her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Furaha 2 Group

texts.en: Scholstica is single and 29 years old with no children. She is a soft-drink seller.

loans.use: Expand the business

loans.name: Bustani Group

texts.en: Ummy is the leader of this loan group. She is married and has 1 child. The other mothers in the group are single mothers and they are planning to use their Kiva loan to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To increase his business capital

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Kitomondo Group

texts.en: Hawa, Zaina, Ashura and Judith are married and have 2 ,1 ,1 and 2 children respectively. They plan to use their Kiva loan to start a clothing business.

loans.use: To start a new business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Butangala A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Fidah N.. She runs a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to change to selling farm produce. Fidah is 23 years old and is married. Her husband works in a restaurant. She has 4 children ranging in age from 1.5 to 8, and only 1 goes to school to school. Each week, Fidah makes approximately 28000 UGX (about $15) profit. With the extra profits resulting from her loan, she hopes to be able to repay the loan and cater for home needs. Fidah previously had a loan from BRAC Uganda for 100000 UGX (about $60) to invest in the business and the loan was paid back on time.

Fidah is joined in her small group by Sarah A., Rose N., and Scovia B.. Sarah A. has a local brewing business and wants to expand her business. Rose N. has a butchery and wants a loan to purchase more animals for slaughtering. Scovia B. sells vegetables and wants to start selling used clothes.

loans.use: To start trading in farm produce

loans.name: Songambele Group

texts.en: Joyce, the leader of this loan group, is a married woman living with her husband and child. She plans to use her loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Tanzania - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Butangala B Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Justine B.. She sells vegetables and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Justine is 32 years old and is married. Her husband works as a commercial motorcyclist. She has 4 children, ranging in age from 2 months to 11 years old, and 3 children go to school.

Each week, Justine makes approximately 7000 UGX (about $4) profit. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to repay the loan and also pay school fees for the children. In the past, Justine had a loan from BRAC Uganda for 70000 UGX (about $40) in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Justine is joined in her small group by Sauda N., Claire S., and Safina N.. Sauda N. has a retail shop and wants to increase the stock. Claire S. also has a retail shop and wants a loan to add more inventory. Safina N. has a restaurant and wants to purchase more furniture and kitchen utensils.

loans.use: To expand vegetable-selling business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Kisakye A Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Florence A.. She sells used clothing and is requesting a loan to expand business. Florence is 35 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has 3 children ranging in age from age 3 months to 10 years old, and her children go to school.

Each week, Florence makes approximately 50000 UGX (about $30) profit. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to provide for the basic needs of the family and home. Previously, Florence had a loan from BRAC Uganda for 200000 UGX (about $120) in order to invest in the business and the loan was paid back on time.

Florence is joined in her small group by Amina N., Topista N., and Rose N.. Amina N. has a retail shop and wants to purchase more items to sell in the shop. Topista N. sells second-hand clothes and wants a loan to purchase more clothes to sell and expand the business. Rose N. runs a retail shop and wants to increase the stock of goods in the shop.

loans.use: To expand the clothing business and earn more to support her family

loans.name: Kisakye B Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Cissy I.. She has a tailoring business and is requesting a loan to improve her business. Cissy is 34 years old and is married. Her husband is a teacher. She has 5 children, ages 2.5 to 15 years old, and 4 of them go to school.

Each week, Cissy makes approximately 60000 UGX (about $35) profit. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy a television and fridge. Previously, Cissy had a loan for 300000 UGX (about $175) from BRAC Uganda in order to invest in business and the loan was paid back on time.

Cissy is joined in her small group by Esta K., Zelipha N., and Else M.. Esta K. has a business selling charcoal and wants to increase her stock of charcoal. Zelipha N. sells used clothing and wants a loan to purchase more clothing to sell. Else M. runs a welding business of welding and wants to make more windows to sell.

loans.use: To improve and increase the tailoring business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Kisakye C Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Joy R.. She sells sweet potatoes and coffee and is requesting a loan to increase the stock of coffee and potatoes. Joy is 40 years old and is married. Her husband sells feed for poultry. She has 6 children ranging in age from 2 months to 18 years old, and 5 of them go to school.

Each week, Joy makes approximately 100000 UGX (about $60) profit. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Previously, Joy had a loan from BRAC Uganda for 300000 UGX (about $175) in order to invest in the business, and the loan was paid back on time.

Joy is joined in her small group by Tofa M.. Tofa M. sells coffee and wants increase her business.

loans.use: To expand food business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Pedro Pablo

texts.es:
Pedro Pablo Sanchez is a gentleman native of Villanueva located in the city of Ghinandega in Nicaragua. For a long time he has been thinking of ways of getting ahead and improving his financial condition, this brought him to the decision to start his own business of selling bread in small quantities.

Currently Mr. Pedro Sanchez has 10 years invested in this business and with great effort he is able to support his two school age children.

It is important to stress that Mr. Pedro finds himself with the need to invest in his small company and due to the lack of resources is turning to Ceprodel for a loan which will enable him to improve the condition of his business and acquire raw materials so that he can continue to support his family. He has a history of 4 loans with Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Bobbit, Kiva volunteer.

Pedro Pablo S. es un caballero originario de Villanueva ubicada en la ciudad de Chinandega de Nicaragua. Por mucho tiempo buscó la manera de salir adelante para mejorar su condición económica lo que lo llevo a pensar en poner su propio negocio y se decidió por vender pan pero en pequeñas cantidades.

Actualmente, el señor Pedro S. lleva 10 años de dedicarse a este negocio y con mucho esfuerzo lo realiza para mantener a sus 2 hijos en edad escolar.

Es necesario destacar que el señor Pedro atraviesa la necesidad de invertir en su negocio y por ser de escasos recursos acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiado con créditos que le ayuden a mejorar la condición del negocio y comprar materia prima para continuar manteniendo su núcleo familiar. Su record crediticio es de 4 créditos con Ceprodel

loans.use: Expansion of the business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: José Ilario

texts.es:
Cabinetmaking requires a lot of hard work and dedication. Cognizant of this fact, Mr. José Ilario has been in this field in the town of las Pilas in the Chinandega district of Nicaragua for over 20 years.

He is a married father of two small children, who are his reason for working hard in order to improve his financial situation. It is important to note that Mr. José Ilario has excelled as a cabinetmaker, which is why he has been able to gain the trust of the town’s residents.

Committed to providing the best service and highest quality for his town, he is looking for a way to improve his business through the purchase of new work tools. Thus, he is seeking the help of Ceprodel, so that he may obtain a loan that will permit him to buy his tools, thus helping him cover his household expenses.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

La ebanistería es un negocio que requiere de mucho esfuerzo y dedicación. Consiente de esto, el señor José Ilario se dedica a este negocio desde hace 20 años en el pueblo las Pilas del departamento de Chinandega en Nicaragua.

Es casado y padre de dos pequeños hijos que son el motivo de sus esfuerzos por mejorar su situación económica. Es importante destacar que el señor José Ilario ha sobresalido por ser un buen ebanista y por tal motivo ha logrado alcanzar la confianza de muchas personas en su pueblo.

Comprometido con su pueblo a brindar un mejor servicio y de alta calidad, busca la manera de mejorar su negocio con la compra de nuevas herramientas para su trabajo y para esto acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiado con créditos que le permitan la compra de sus herramientas y así continuar supliendo las necesidades de su hogar.

loans.use: Purchase of work tools

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Emerita

texts.es:
Emerita R. is a hardworking person who sells bread, food, instant soup, deodorants, razors, fashion jewelry, etc. In short, she has been running a small grocery store in the Villanueva district of Chinandega for 20 years.

Her greatest motive for keeping this business is her two small children, whom she loves very much. She asserts that her greatest wish is to see her children obtain a college degree and become successful people in life. Despite having gone through financially difficult times, Emerita has requested loans from Ceprodel in order to restock her mini market, thus permitting her to get ahead in life. She has obtained a total of 8 loans.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Emerita R. es un apersona muy esforzada que se dedica a la venta de pan, comestibles, sopas instantáneas, desodorantes, afeitadoras, bisuterías, etc. En fin es una tienda de víveres que la administra desde hace 20 años en la ciudad de Chinandega específicamente en el pueblo de Villanueva.

Su mayor motivo para seguir con este negocio han sido sus dos pequeños a los que ama mucho y afirma que son sus mayores deseos que ellos coronen una carrera universitaria para ser personas de éxito en la vida. A pesar de haber pasado por momentos muy complicados hablando financieramente, Emerita ha solicitado créditos en Ceprodel para surtir las necesidades de la pulpería y de esta manera salir adelante. Su record crediticio es de 8 créditos.

loans.use: Restock her small general store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CEPRODEL - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Alicia's Group

texts.en:
Alicia, Maruja, and Pelaya are members of the community bank “Empecemos”. Alicia and Pelaya have been belonged to the bank for two years. Maruja joined just four months ago. In that time they learned about punctuality, responsibility, and how to manage their businesses. In addition, they have learned about self-esteem and family relationships.

Alicia is 33 years old. She is married and has four daughters. Alicia sells children’s clothing. Once per month she travels to nine hours to the city of Lima to buy products and then sells them from her home.

Maruja is 25 years old. She is married and has two sons. Maruja has been selling cosmetic products to her friends and family for one year. Previously, she sold fruit but this required a large degree of travel and time away from her family.

Pelaya is 45 years old. She is married and has four children. Pelaya buys grains in the city of Ayacucho and sells them at a regional three hours away. From this market she buys a variety of fruits and sells them in Ayacucho.

Alicia, Maruja, and Pelaya need loans of 400, 400, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to start selling shoes, buy cosmetics, wheat, barley, corn, and fruit.

One of the key aspects of the community business is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Alicia, Maruja, and Pelaya plan to use their savings to improve their homes, and pay unexpected expenses. Their dreams are to be powerful as a woman, own a store, continue to progress forward, and see their children have a better life.

loans.use: Alicia, Maruja, and Pelaya need loans of 400, 400, and 600 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to start selling shoes, buy cosmetics, wheat, barley, corn, and fruit.

loans.name: Camilia Lyli

texts.es:
Señora Camila is a merchant who has a lot of experience selling women's and men's clothing, cosmetics, and appliances for the home. She developed this business in her home and has expanded it. She now offers a larger variety of products, styles, brands, and prices.

She has a good number of clients who buy and order from her. She dedicates her entire day to her business. She buys the products that she sells in the central market at favorable prices since she buys them in large volumes. She started her business 14 years ago by selling only clothing and cosmetics. Today it is larger due to her good administration. This has let her educate her three daughters, who now live independently.

Camila needs a loan right now to buy home applicances that her clients have ordered from her like televisions, radios, and DVD players, among other things. Her clients have the ease of acquiring these appliances on credit that they can pay off weekly, bi-weekly, or monthly.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva volunteer
